title_original: Condicionantes ambientais dos padrões de beta-diversidade em comunidades de anfíbios no Cerrado
title_english: Environmental drivers of beta-diversity patterns in amphibian communities in the Cerrado
abstract_original: Foi utilizada a ferramenta de Modelos Generalizados de Dissimilaridade para descrever a relação entre dissimilaridades ambientais e biológicas em comunidades de anuros no Cerrado e definir sub-regiões onde são esperadas faunas mais similares, em função das caracteristias ambientais. Os fatores que mais contribuíram para o modelo foram inclinação do terreno, precipitação anual e temperatura mínima, que estão diretamente relacionados à disponibilidade e à duração de sítios reprodutivos, bem como aos limites de tolerância fisiológica dos anfíbios. As sub-regiões do Cerrado com maior sobreposição com o envelope ambiental da Mata Atlântica apresentaram maior número de espécies exclusivas e refletem os altos valores de endemismo das comunidades deste bioma. Por outro lado, sub-regiões com sobreposição com o envelope ambiental da Amazônia e Caatinga, apresentaram poucas espécies exclusivas e refletem os baixos níveis de endemismo restrito em comunidades de ambos os biomas
abstract_english: The Generalized Dissimilarity Models tool was used to describe the relationship between environmental and biological dissimilarities in anuran communities in the Cerrado and define sub-regions where more similar faunas are expected, depending on environmental characteristics. The factors that contributed most to the model were land slope, annual precipitation and minimum temperature, which are directly related to the availability and duration of breeding sites, as well as to the physiological tolerance limits of amphibians. The Cerrado sub-regions with greater overlap with the Atlantic Forest environmental envelope showed higher numbers of unique species and reflect the high endemism values of the communities of this biome. On the other hand, sub-regions with overlapping environmental envelopes of the Amazon and Caatinga, showed few exclusive species and reflect the low levels of restricted endemism in communities of both biomes

title_original: Should I stay or should I go? Costs and benefits of paternal care in a harvestman species
title_english: Should I stay or should I go? Costs and benefits of paternal care in a harvestman species
abstract_original: É esperado  que o comportamento de cuidado parental evolua apenas quando os benefícios em termos de aumento de sobrevivência da prole sejam maiores do que os custos pagos pelos indivíduos parentais por exibirem este comportamento. Nesta apresentação, irei mostrar resultados obtidos com uma espécie de opilião (Iporangaia pustulosa) que apresenta cuidado paternal, na qual quantifiquei os efeitos do cuidado sobre a sobrevivência dos ovos, assim como sobre a condição física dos machos guardiões, a sobrevivência desses adultos e suas oportunidades adicionais de cópula. Este é o primeiro estudo realizado em condições naturais a quantificar de forma completa os custos e os benefícios do cuidado paternal em uma espécie de artrópode. Irei mostrar que a guarda dos ovos pelos machos é essencial para a sobrevivência dos ovos, visto que a predação é relativamente alta na área estudada. Em decorrência disso, os machos permanecem muito tempo associados às suas desovas, restringindo seu forrageamento e, consequentemente, apresentam um decaimento em suas condições físicas ao longo do período de cuidado. Entretanto, não existe um efeito negativo sobre a sobrevivência dos indivíduos parentais que, na verdade, apresentam uma taxa de sobrevivência mais alta do que outros indivíduos na população que não cuidam dos ovos. Finalmente, o cuidado paternal não restringe a aquisição de novas cópulas pelos machos guardiões mas sim aumenta sua atratividade frente a novas parceiras sexuais. Assim, o cuidado paternal em I. pustulosa apresenta custos excepcionalmente baixos em relação aos grandes benefícios usufruídos tanto pela prole quanto pelos machos guardiões.
abstract_english: It is expected that parental caring behavior will evolve only when the benefits in terms of increased offspring survival are greater than the costs paid by parental individuals for exhibiting this behavior. In this presentation, I will show results obtained with an opilion species (Iporangaia pustulosa) that exhibits parental care, in which I quantified the effects of care on egg survival, as well as on the fitness of the guardian males, the survival of these adults, and their additional copulation opportunities. This is the first study conducted under natural conditions to fully quantify the costs and benefits of paternal care in an arthropod species. I will show that egg guarding by males is essential for egg survival, since predation is relatively high in the area studied. As a result, males remain associated with their spawn for a long time, restricting their foraging, and consequently show a decline in their physical condition over the care period. However, there is no negative effect on the survival of parental individuals, which in fact have a higher survival rate than other individuals in the population that do not care for eggs. Finally, paternal care does not restrict the acquisition of new copulations by guardian males but rather increases their attractiveness to new sexual partners. Thus, paternal care in I. pustulosa has exceptionally low costs in relation to the large benefits enjoyed by both the offspring and the guardian males.

title_original: Homogenization of suburban bird assemblages: an Australian perspective
title_english: Homogenization of suburban bird assemblages: an Australian perspective
abstract_original: Much of the research on homogenisation of urban bird assemblages has focused on identifying traits of invading species or invaded habitats.  The research has also focused on a relatively small group of commensal or synanthropic bird species common to centres of cities throughout the Northern Hemisphere.  Less attention has been paid to suburban areas within large cities of the south, states of flux in assemblages, and to spatial and temporal disjunctions within cities.  The research reported here was conducted in Melbourne, Australia; a metropolis of approximately four million people covering some 880,000 ha, established in 1835.  It is built on lava flows to the west, sedimentary hills to the east, and sand sheets to the southeast.  Data on bird occurrence were extracted from the Birds Australia Atlas II database, and aggregated into species lists within 1-km2 grid cells.  Patterns of species abundance and distribution were examined using ordination, hierarchical cluster analysis, and guild analysis.  Relationships with environmental and human demographic gradients were also analysed.  Due the effects of strong geographic differences in topography, geography and rainfall, which related strongly to bird assemblages organised by foraging, nest substrate and dispersal guilds, the data were partitioned into eastern and western subsets and re-analysed.  Bird assemblages of recently developed areas of Melbourne in the west appeared to be in a state of flux, in the early stages of converging towards the more established suburban and urban assemblage patterns evident in the older parts of eastern Melbourne.  Urban areas may need to be environmentally partitioned before the pattern of their bird assemblages can be fully understood.
abstract_english: Much of the research on homogenisation of urban bird assemblages has focused on identifying traits of invading species or invaded habitats.  The research has also focused on a relatively small group of commensal or synanthropic bird species common to centres of cities throughout the Northern Hemisphere.  Less attention has been paid to suburban areas within large cities of the south, states of flux in assemblages, and to spatial and temporal disjunctions within cities.  The research reported here was conducted in Melbourne, Australia; a metropolis of approximately four million people covering some 880,000 ha, established in 1835. title_original: Hunting for livelihoods in tropical forests: examples from the Congo Basin
title_english: Hunting for livelihoods in tropical forests: examples from the Congo Basin
abstract_original: The word bushmeat crisis although originating in Africa, is now widely used across tropical areas and tends to be used to describe overhunting of wildlife for human consumption in tropical areas. Several studies have documented bushmeat as the main source of dietary protein and one of the most important sources of income for rural people in Central Africa, where the current annual harvest could exceed two million tonnes. There is evidence illustrating that the scale of hunting, occurring in these regions, poses a threat to many tropical forest species. Local extinctions of hunted species are widespread in West and Central Africa. However, the long-term persistence of the bushmeat trade suggests that the trade can be sustainable. Vulnerable taxa (slow reproducers) support low levels of hunting and are often depleted in hunted areas, but robust taxa (fast reproducers), such as rodents and small antelopes, are resilient to hunting pressure and persist even in agricultural landscapes around the cities. In this lecture, I would like to address the following thematic areas:  1. The extend and the importance of the bushmeat crisis” in Central Africa and the ecological impacts of overharvesting; 2. Challenges in measuring the sustainability of hunting; 3. The economic importance of the  bushmeat sector; 4. Consumption  patterns and nutritional value of bushmeat; 5. Key factors influencing the demand for bushmeat; 6. The dynamics of the bushmeat trade; 7. The determinants of bushmeat consumption; and  8. Recommendations for a sustainable use of wildlife resources. I hope this lecture will motivate a participatory discussion on inter continental comparisons concerning the use of wildlife  resources for food.
abstract_english: The word bushmeat crisis although originating in Africa, is now widely used across tropical areas and tends to be used to describe overhunting of wildlife for human consumption in tropical areas. I hope this lecture will motivate a participatory discussion on inter continental comparisons concerning the use of wildlife  resources for food.

title_original: Water bird communities in artificial wetlands: community structure and management strategies
title_english: Water bird communities in artificial wetlands: community structure and management strategies
abstract_original: In the last 30 years, more than 2700 irrigation ponds have been constructed in the southeastern Spain to store the water for agricultural purposes. The ponds are located within a network of wetlands with international importance for waterbids. Several bird species use the ponds both in the breeding and in the wintering season to breed, forage and rest. Therefore, a more detailed knowledge of the processes shaping waterbirds distribution in the ponds can be used to develop management strategies to conceal conservation and agricultural use. Moreover, the system ponds-waterbirds can be used to test some of the theoretical patterns in ecology
abstract_english: In the last 30 years, more than 2700 irrigation ponds have been constructed in the southeastern Spain to store the water for agricultural purposes. The ponds are located within a network of wetlands with international importance for waterbids. Several bird species use the ponds both in the breeding and in the wintering season to breed, forage and rest. Moreover, the system ponds-waterbirds can be used to test some of the theoretical patterns in ecology

title_original: Effects of habitat amount on a landscape scale on demographic mechanisms in Atlantic forest small mammals
title_english: Effects of habitat quantity in the landscape on demographic mechanisms in small mammals in the Atlantic Forest
abstract_original:
Although the amount of remaining habitat in fragmented landscapes is likely to have an impact on biodiversity patterns, few fragmentation studies include this parameter. In the highly fragmented coastal Atlantic forest, investigations on the amount of remaining forest showed a significant effect on abundance of the endemic small mammal species: while abundance was independent of fragment size in a landscape with 100 and 50 % of remaining forest, abundance was positively correlated with fragment size in a landscape with only 30 % of remaining forest. To understand demographic processes leading to this pattern, we studied the demography of four small mammal species (one endemic marsupial, two endemic rodents, one non-endemic rodent) in small fragments and continuous forest of these landscapes using population parameter modeling in the program MARK. We investigated demographic parameters and used Akaike´s information criterion (AIC) for model selection to define most parsimonious models, which were used for parameter estimation. We tested the hypothesis that amount of habitat on a landscape scale influences immigration into fragments from neighboring habitat patches. 
Models selection procedures favored models comprising higher survival in small fragments of the 50 % landscape compared to small fragments of the 30 % landscape for endemic species. Moreover, a lower number of immigrants was calculated in the 30 % landscape compared to the 50% and the 100% landscape for endemic species. For the non-endemic species, amount of habitat had no influence on immigration rates. 
The results underline the necessity to consider the amount of remaining habitat in management plans of fragmented landscapes in order to successfully maintain endemic small mammal species.
abstract_english:
Although the amount of remaining habitat in fragmented landscapes is likely to have an impact on biodiversity patterns, few fragmentation studies include this parameter. In the highly fragmented coastal Atlantic forest, investigations on the amount of remaining forest showed a significant effect on abundance of the endemic small mammal species: while abundance was independent of fragment size in a landscape with 100 and 50 % of remaining forest, abundance was positively correlated with fragment size in a landscape with only 30 % of remaining forest. To understand demographic processes leading to this pattern, we studied the demography of four small mammal species (one endemic marsupial, two endemic rodents, one non-endemic rodent) in small fragments and continuous forest of these landscapes using population parameter modeling in the program MARK. We investigated demographic parameters and used Akaike´s information criterion (AIC) for model selection to define most parsimonious models, which were used for parameter estimation. We tested the hypothesis that amount of habitat on a landscape scale influences immigration into fragments from neighboring habitat patches. 
Models selection procedures favored models comprising higher survival in small fragments of the 50 % landscape compared to small fragments of the 30 % landscape for endemic species. Moreover, a lower number of immigrants was calculated in the 30 % landscape compared to the 50% and the 100% landscape for endemic species. For the non-endemic species, amount of habitat had no influence on immigration rates. 
The results underline the necessity to consider the amount of remaining habitat in management plans of fragmented landscapes in order to successfully maintain endemic small mammal species.

title_original: Fauna de cupim na região do médio Rio Madeira
title_english: Termite fauna in the middle Madeira River region
abstract_original: In the region known as the middle Madeira River", which is located upstream of the portion of the river that passes through Porto Velho, Rondônia, the Santo Antônio and Jirau Hydroelectric Power Plants (AHEs) will be created. The alignment of the Amazon-Madeira-Mamoré rivers separates the Neotropical region into two areas of endemism for various groups of invertebrates and vertebrates, however, nothing has been tested for termites to date. Some estimates suggest that these insects may account for up to 20% of the animal biomass in some areas of the Amazon. However, termites are still poorly known in this biome and new species are constantly being found and described. Thus, the objectives of this work are: 1- Survey and collect data on the biology and ecology of termite species present in the areas of the AHEs; 2- Comparison of species composition on each side of the Madeira River; and 3- Study of the genetic structure of the most abundant species that are present on both sides of the Madeira River - to infer the existence of gene flow between populations on each bank. To this end, quarterly collections are being made in modules based on the criteria of the Biodiversity Research Program (PPBio) on the banks of the Madeira River. The study of genetic structure will be done through analysis of sequenced Mitochondrial Gene COI. Some collections have already been made and the study area can already be considered one of the most diverse for these insects".
abstract_english: In the region known as the Middle Madeira", which is located upstream of the part of the river that flows through Porto Velho, Rondônia, the Santo Antônio and Jirau Hydroelectric Power Plants (AHEs) will be created. The alignment of the Amazon-Madeira-Mamoré rivers separates the Neotropical region into two areas of endemism for various groups of invertebrates and vertebrates, however, nothing has been tested for termites to date. Some estimates suggest that these insects may account for up to 20% of the animal biomass in some areas of the Amazon. However, termites are still poorly known in this biome and new species are constantly being found and described. Thus, the objectives of this work are: 1- Survey and collect data on the biology and ecology of termite species present in the areas of the AHEs; 2- Comparison of species composition on each side of the Madeira River; and 3- Study of the genetic structure of the most abundant species present on both sides of the Madeira River - to infer the existence of gene flow between populations on each bank. For this purpose, quarterly collections are being made in modules based on the criteria of the Biodiversity Research Program (PPBio) on the banks of the Madeira River. The study of genetic structure will be done through the analysis of the Mitochondrial sequenced COI gene. Some collections have already been made and the study area can already be considered one of the most diverse for these insects.

title_original: Corredores florestais promovem conectividade? Uma abordagem experimental
title_english: Do forest corridors promote connectivity? An experimental approach
abstract_original: Uma das estratégias mais populares para manter ou restabelecer a conectividade biológica em paisagens fragmentadas é a retenção ou implantação de corredores florestais. Não obstante, evidências empíricas de que corredores promovem conectividade para organismos de floresta tropical são escassas. Não existem, por exemplo, evidências diretas de que corredores promovam ou facilitem a movimentação de aves neotropicais de sub-bosque por paisagens fragmentadas. Usando translocações experimentais combinadas com rádio-telemetria nós avaliamos os efeitos de corredores florestais e de sexo sobre a movimentação de uma ave de sub-bosque (Pyriglena leucoptera, Passeriformes, Thamnophilidae) entre fragmentos florestais. Indivíduos capturados em floresta contínua foram soltos em pequenos fragmentos florestais menores do que sua área de vida, divididos em dois tratamentos: i) isolado – fragmentos completamente rodeados por matrizes campestres e ii) conectado – fragmentos rodeados por matrizes campestres, porém conectados por um corredor florestal a um fragmento vizinho de maior área. Um macho e uma fêmea foram translocados, um de cada vez, para cada fragmento de soltura. Então foram medidos (1) o tempo no qual cada ave permaneceu no fragmento de soltura (propensão à emigração), (2) a direção tomada por cada ave ao abandonar o fragmento de soltura e (3) se os indivíduos foram bem-sucedidos em realizar pelo menos um movimento entre fragmentos. A presença de corredores aumentou a propensão à emigração, direcionou os movimentos dos indivíduos e aumentou o número de indivíduos que realizaram movimentos bem sucedidos entre fragmentos. No tratamento conectado ambos os sexos abandonaram rapidamente os fragmentos de soltura, na maioria das vezes via corredor, e evitando áreas abertas. Já no tratamento isolado, os machos foram mais relutantes do que as fêmeas em emigrar e tiveram duas vezes menos sucesso em realizar movimentos entre fragmentos. Nossos resultados indicam que corredores florestais aumentam a conectividade da paisagem para P. leucoptera, e sugerem que a fragmentação florestal diminui mais severamente os movimentos dos machos do que das fêmeas - o que poderia levar a desvios na razão sexual em fragmentos isolados. Nossos resultados sugerem, ainda, que corredores são ferramentas úteis para a conservação desta espécie (e de outras com características semelhantes) em paisagens fragmentadas pelo homem
abstract_english: One of the most popular strategies for maintaining or restoring biological connectivity in fragmented landscapes is the retention or establishment of forest corridors. Nevertheless, empirical evidence that corridors promote connectivity for tropical forest organisms is scarce. For example, there is no direct evidence that corridors promote or facilitate the movement of neotropical understory birds through fragmented landscapes. Using experimental translocations combined with radio-telemetry we evaluated the effects of forest corridors and sex on the movement of an understory bird (Pyriglena leucoptera, Passeriformes, Thamnophilidae) between forest fragments. Individuals captured in continuous forest were released in small forest fragments smaller than their home range, divided into two treatments: i) isolated - fragments completely surrounded by matrices and ii) connected - fragments surrounded by matrices but connected by a forest corridor to a neighboring larger fragment. One male and one female were translocated, one at a time, to each release patch. Then we measured (1) how long each bird remained in the release patch (propensity to emigrate), (2) the direction each bird took when leaving the release patch, and (3) whether individuals were successful in making at least one movement between patches. The presence of corridors increased the propensity to emigrate, directed the movements of individuals, and increased the number of individuals that made successful movements between fragments. In the connected treatment both sexes quickly left the release fragments, mostly via corridor, and avoiding open areas. In the isolated treatment, males were more reluctant than females to emigrate and were twice as unsuccessful in making movements between fragments. Our results indicate that forest corridors increase landscape connectivity for P. leucoptera, and suggest that forest fragmentation decreases male movements more severely than female movements - which could lead to shifts in sex ratio in isolated fragments. Our results also suggest that corridors are useful tools for the conservation of this species (and others with similar characteristics) in human-fragmented landscapes

title_original: Ecologia de anêmonas
title_english: Ecology of anemones
abstract_original: Anêmonas-do-mar do gênero Diadumene Stephenson, 1920 são encontradas em  grande número fixadas sobre substratos naturais e estruturas artificiais na Baía de  Paranaguá. Em trabalho realizado vinte anos antes e no mesmo local, a freqüência dessas anêmonas foi baixa. O grande número atual pode ser explicado por sua alta taxa de reprodução assexuada, por fissão longitudinal, um dos fatores que poderia caracterizar essas anêmonas como sendo uma espécie invasora. Acredita-se que os indivíduos encontrados em Paranaguá pertençam à espécie Diadumene cincta Stephenson, 1925, que apresenta registros na literatura que a caracterizam como espécie exótica e invasora nos mares europeus e na costa atlântica européia. A sistemática no nível específico dessas anêmonas deverá ser esclarecida e será testada a tolerância para diferentes salinidades, à dessecação e preferência por locais iluminados, sendo que os dois primeiros testes revelariam se existe uma adaptabilidade característica de espécies invasoras, e o último sua capacidade de colonizar um local de águas calmas, mas onde há grande interferência humana por ser um porto movimentado. É de importância o reconhecimento específico do invasor e da sua biologia com potencial invasor pela adaptabilidade, pois talvez a elaboração de medidas de prevenção contra sua dispersão descontrolada exigirá um esforço financeiro e pessoal muito menor do que a realização de esforços para controlar uma população já bem estabelecida
abstract_english: Sea anemones of the genus Diadumene Stephenson, 1920 are found in large numbers fixed on natural substrates and artificial structures in Paranaguá Bay. In a study carried out twenty years earlier at the same site, the frequency of these anemones was low. The present large number can be explained by their high rate of asexual reproduction by longitudinal fission, one of the factors that could characterize these anemones as an invasive species. It is believed that the individuals found in Paranaguá belong to the species Diadumene cincta Stephenson, 1925, which has records in the literature that characterize it as an exotic and invasive species in European seas and the European Atlantic coast. The systematics at the specific level of these anemones should be clarified and their tolerance to different salinities, to desiccation, and preference for illuminated sites will be tested. The first two tests would reveal if there is an adaptability characteristic of invasive species, and the last one its ability to colonize a site of calm waters, but where there is great human interference because it is a busy port. It is of importance the specific recognition of the invader and its biology with invasive potential by adaptability, because perhaps the development of preventive measures against its uncontrolled dispersion will require much less financial and personal effort than efforts to control an already well-established population

title_original: Estratégias alternativas de acasalamento e dimorfismo condicional entre machos do opilião Serracutisoma proximum (Arachnida: Opiliones)
title_english: Alternative mating strategies and conditional dimorphism among males of the opilion Serracutisoma proximum (Arachnida: Opiliones)
abstract_original: Nessa apresentação eu descreverei o dimorfismo entre machos e as estratégias alternativas de acasalamento no opilião Serracutisoma proximum. Machos grandes possuem o segundo par de pernas mais alongado e as usam em brigas territoriais; machos pequenos possuem o segundo par de pernas relativamente curto e nunca brigam - ao invés disso esses machos invadem furtivamente o território dos machos grandes e copulam com as fêmeas que guardam seus ovos nesses territórios. Em artrópodes, a maioria dos casos de dimorfismo morfológico entre machos é o resultado de uma estratégia condicional com duas táticas dependentes de status (i.e., a condição física relativa de cada indivíduo). Em espécies com machos condicionalmente dimórficos, as distribuições de status dos dois morfos de machos freqüentemente possuem alguma sobreposição. O modelo do limiar ambiental (LA) postula que cada genótipo na população possui um status limiar próprio, que é o valor de status abaixo do qual o morfo pequeno é expressado, e acima do qual o morfo grande é expressado. Conseqüentemente, a magnitude da sobreposição nas distribuições de status dos dois morfos de machos depende da variabilidade genética nos limiares. De fato, em S. proximum, a maneira como o tamanho do segundo par de pernas varia em relação ao tamanho de corpo dos machos revela que o fenótipo dos machos grandes depende do tamanho de corpo (status), e que o limiar responsável pelo dimorfismo apresenta um grande componente de variabilidade genética na população. Essa grande variabilidade genética provavelmente resulta de baixa pressão de seleção nesse caráter. Um estudo de marcação e recaptura evidencia que a expressão do fenótipo maior não resulta em custos de sobrevivência, o que é compatível com a hipótese de que a pressão de seleção sobre o limiar do dimorfismo é fraca. Finalmente, apresentarei uma evidência de que o limiar médio da população é independente da distribuição de tamanhos de corpos dos machos, o que apóia uma nova previsão do modelo LA.”
abstract_english: In this presentation I will describe male dimorphism and alternative mating strategies in the opilion Serracutisoma proximum. Large males have the longer second pair of legs and use them in territorial fights; small males have the relatively short second pair of legs and never fight - instead these males sneak into the territory of the large males and copulate with the females that guard their eggs in these territories. In arthropods, most cases of morphological dimorphism among males are the result of a conditional strategy with two status-dependent tactics (i.e., the relative physical condition of each individual). In species with conditionally dimorphic males, the status distributions of the two male morphs often have some overlap. The environmental threshold (LA) model postulates that each genotype in the population has its own threshold status, which is the status value below which the small morph is expressed, and above which the large morph is expressed. Consequently, the magnitude of the overlap in the status distributions of the two male morphs depends on the genetic variability in the thresholds. Indeed, in S. proximum, the manner in which the size of the second pair of legs varies with respect to male body size reveals that the phenotype of large males depends on body size (status), and that the threshold responsible for dimorphism has a large component of genetic variability in the population. This large genetic variability probably results from low selection pressure on this character. A mark-recapture study evidences that expression of the larger phenotype does not result in survival costs, which is compatible with the hypothesis that selection pressure on the threshold of dimorphism is weak. Finally, I will present evidence that the population mean threshold is independent of the body size distribution of males, which supports a new prediction of the LA model."

title_original: Community consequences of size-dependent life histories
title_english: Community consequences of size-dependent life histories
abstract_original: Many processes in the life history of individual organisms depend on body size. Yet, classical models in ecology model population dynamics by accounting only for reproduction and mortality of individuals. They hence ignore the population dynamical influence of individual life history, in particular growth and development. Physiologically or size-structured population models contrast with this approach by describing population dynamics on the basis of a core model of the individual life history.  Changes in population density and composition are hence tracked by keeping book of all the events in the life history of the individuals that make up the population. These models thereby provide an explicit link between individual life history and population dynamics. One crucial outcome of taking into account size-dependent life histories is that the size-distribution of a prey population may be changed by predation mortality. These changes in turn have been shown to generate positive, indirect effects for the predators themselves. They can lead to positive feedbacks between foraging by predators and availability of their food, resulting in so-called emergent Allee effects. Similarly, changes in prey size-distribution may lead to facilitation between different predator species. I provide an overview of the consequences and relevance of these indirect effects of changing population size distributions for ecological communities.”
abstract_english: Many processes in the life history of individual organisms depend on body size. Yet, classical models in ecology model population dynamics by accounting only for reproduction and mortality of individuals. They hence ignore the population dynamical influence of individual life history, in particular growth and development. Physiologically or size-structured population models contrast with this approach by describing population dynamics on the basis of a core model of the individual life history.  Changes in population density and composition are hence tracked by keeping book of all the events in the life history of the individuals that make up the population. These models thereby provide an explicit link between individual life history and population dynamics. One crucial outcome of taking into account size-dependent life histories is that the size-distribution of a prey population may be changed by predation mortality. These changes in turn have been shown to generate positive, indirect effects for the predators themselves. They can lead to positive feedbacks between foraging by predators and availability of their food, resulting in so-called emergent Allee effects. Similarly, changes in prey size-distribution may lead to facilitation between different predator species. I provide an overview of the consequences and relevance of these indirect effects of changing population size distributions for ecological communities.”

title_original: Research plays an active role in cultural and didactical activities in natural history museums
title_english: Research plays an active role in cultural and didactical activities in natural history museums
abstract_original: You know exactly what a researcher does. However, many people do not image what research may offer directly to pupils, high school students (and their teachers). In our university museum we have been experimenting during the last 15 years a simple, albeit effective, way to propose didactical projects mediated by research experience. Some cases will be discussed and commented with you”.

title_original: Comportamento animal em zeros e uns: filogenia de uma família de opiliões e padrões evolutivos de caracteres comportamentais
title_english: Animal behavior in zeros and ones: phylogeny of an opilion family and evolutionary patterns of behavioral traits
abstract_original: A ordem Opiliones contém cerca de 6000 espécies divididas em quatro subordens e 45 famílias. Dentre essas famílias, a família Gonyleptidae (Arachnida, Opiliones) se destaca por sua enorme diversidade e por concentrar a maioria dos estudos sobre biologia de opiliões. Este estudo, valeu-se dessa grande disponibilidade de informações ecológicas, comportamentais e químicas para reconstruir as relações de parentesco entre as subfamílias de Gonyleptidae. Posteriormente, com base nas topologias obtidas, discutimos os padrões de evolução dessas características dentro da família. A listagem de terminais compreende 31 espécies (4 representantes do grupo externo e 27 do grupo interno), levantamos 48 caracteres e 72 estados derivados. A filogenia resultante é parcialmente congruente com as propostas baseadas em caracteres morfológicos. Os altos valores dos índices de consistência das árvores, associado aos altos valores de suporte obtidos para vários clados (especialmente subfamílias), indicam que comportamento e ecologia são fontes de caracteres filogeneticamente informativos e que devem ser considerados em estudos futuros com a família. Embora caracteres ecológico-comportamentais já tenham sido utilizados em estudos cladísticos anteriores, esta é a primeira vez que o monofiletismo de uma família de Arthropoda é formalmente definido exclusivamente com base em caracteres de natureza não morfológica ou molecular”.
abstract_english: The order Opiliones contains about 6000 species divided into four suborders and 45 families. Among these families, the family Gonyleptidae (Arachnida, Opiliones) stands out for its enormous diversity and for concentrating most of the studies on opilion biology. This study, took advantage of this great availability of ecological, behavioral and chemical information to reconstruct the kinship relationships among the subfamilies of Gonyleptidae. Subsequently, based on the topologies obtained, we discussed the patterns of evolution of these traits within the family. The terminal listing comprises 31 species (4 representatives of the outer group and 27 of the inner group), we surveyed 48 characters and 72 derived states. The resulting phylogeny is partially congruent with proposals based on morphological characters. The high values of the tree consistency indices, associated with the high support values obtained for several clades (especially subfamilies), indicate that behavior and ecology are sources of phylogenetically informative characters that should be considered in future studies with the family. Although ecological-behavioral characters have been used in previous cladistic studies, this is the first time that the monophyly of an Arthropoda family is formally defined solely on the basis of characters of a non-morphological or molecular nature."

title_original: A inclusão da abundância na diversidade funcional aumenta o seu poder de previsão? Teste em uma comunidade de cerrado
title_english: Does including abundance in functional diversity increase its predictive power? Test in a cerrado community
abstract_original: Assumindo que medidas de diversidade tradicionais são estimativas grosseiras do funcionamento de comunidades e que medidas que incorporam informações dos traços funcionais são melhores do que as tradicionais, medidas de diversidade funcional são bastante utilizadas atualmente. Contudo, raramente é testado se, de fato, a inclusão dos traços funcionais em estimativas de biodiversidade aumenta nosso poder preditivo. Além disso, medidas de diversidade funcional baseadas em dendrogramas geralmente não consideram a abundância. Em uma área de cerrado no sudeste brasileiro, testamos se a inclusão dos traços funcionais leva a um aumento no poder preditivo ao relacionar a diversidade funcional ao funcionamento da comunidade quando comparada a medidas de diversidade tradicionais. Demonstramos que é possível incluir a abundância em medidas de diversidade funcional baseadas em dendrogramas e testamos se a inclusão da abundância eleva o poder preditivo da diversidade funcional em comparação à comumente calculada. Nenhuma medida de diversidade relacionou-se ao funcionamento da comunidade, inclusive a diversidade funcional. Porém, mostramos que é possível incluir a abundância em medidas de diversidade funcional baseadas em dendrogramas, apesar da maioria dos índices estar correlacionada”
abstract_english:
"Assuming that traditional diversity measures are crude estimates of community functioning and that measures that incorporate information from functional traits are better than traditional ones, functional diversity measures are widely used today. However, it is rarely tested whether, in fact, including functional traits in biodiversity estimates increases our predictive power. In addition, dendrogram-based measures of functional diversity generally do not consider abundance. In a cerrado area in southeastern Brazil, we tested whether the inclusion of functional traits leads to an increase in predictive power when relating functional diversity to community functioning when compared to traditional diversity measures. We demonstrate that it is possible to include abundance in dendrogram-based measures of functional diversity and test whether the inclusion of abundance raises the predictive power of functional diversity compared to that commonly calculated. No diversity measure was related to community functioning, including functional diversity. However, we show that it is possible to include abundance in dendrogram-based measures of functional diversity, despite most indices being correlated."
"

title_original: Ecologia cognitiva e forrageio social em primatas Neotropicais
title_english: Cognitive ecology and social foraging in Neotropical primates
abstract_original: O conhecimento sobre a composição da dieta dos primatas neotropicais e sua relação com a morfologia, o comportamento e a organização social entre outros aspectos da biologia das espécies cresceu significativamente nas últimas décadas. Enquanto os estudos de observação de campo, tradicionais na primatologia, permitem identificar um conjunto de desafios que os animais enfrentam durante as suas atividades diárias, eles são pouco informativos em relação às dicas ambientais utilizadas pelos macacos na tomada de decisões de forrageio e como as decisões individuais são afetadas pela vida em grupo. Portanto, a ecologia cognitiva e o forrageio social representam duas importantes fronteiras da primatologia neotropical e mundial. Neste sentido, uma abordagem experimental de campo tem sido adotada para testar hipóteses referentes à relevância e primazia de diferentes informações ambientais e sociais durante o forrageio. O desenho experimental envolve a construção de estações de alimentação artificiais onde a presença de dicas visuais e olfativas e a localização e quantidade de recompensas alimentares são manipuladas. As espécies de macacos brasileiros estudadas até o momento incluem Cebus nigritus, Callicebus cupreus, Aotus nigriceps, Saguinus imperator, S. fuscicollis, S. bicolor, Callithrix penicillata, híbridos (Callithrix jacchus x C. penicillata), Leontopithecus rosalia e Alouatta guarida clamitans.”
abstract_english: Knowledge about the diet composition of Neotropical primates and its relationship with morphology, behavior and social organization among other aspects of species biology has grown significantly in recent decades. While field observation studies, traditional in primatology, allow us to identify a set of challenges that animals face during their daily activities, they are uninformative regarding the environmental cues used by monkeys in making foraging decisions and how individual decisions are affected by group life. Therefore, cognitive ecology and social foraging represent two important frontiers of Neotropical and global primatology. In this regard, a field experimental approach has been adopted to test hypotheses regarding the relevance and primacy of different environmental and social information during foraging. The experimental design involves the construction of artificial feeding stations where the presence of visual and olfactory cues and the location and amount of food rewards are manipulated. Brazilian monkey species studied to date include Cebus nigritus, Callicebus cupreus, Aotus nigriceps, Saguinus imperator, S. fuscicollis, S. bicolor, Callithrix penicillata, hybrids (Callithrix jacchus x C. penicillata), Leontopithecus rosalia, and Alouatta guarida clamitans."

title_original: Heterogeneidades espaciais e mecanismos de coexistência floresta-campo no sul do Brasil
title_english: Spatial heterogeneities and mechanisms of forest-field coexistence in southern Brazil
abstract_original:
Os fatores e os mecanismos que permitem a coexistência entre formações campestres
e florestais ao longo de períodos com diferentes regimes climáticos dominantes ainda não
são completamente esclarecidos. Atualmente, no Rio Grande do Sul, a vegetação natural
caracteriza-se pelo domínio de campos naturais entremeados por diferentes tipos florestais
sob condições climáticas que favoreceriam o predomínio florestal. Evidências paleopolínicas
indicam que os campos naturais são relictos de climas passados mais frios e secos e que as
florestas iniciaram sua expansão sobre os campos a partir de 4000 anos antes do presentes,
sob influência de alterações climáticas de transição para um clima mais úmido. Neste
sentido, o esclarecimento das relações espaciais e temporais entre os fatores e os mecanismos
que favoreceriam o estabelecimento e a sobrevivência de elementos florestais numa matriz
campestre permite o entendimento de como os padrões de distribuição da vegetação na
paisagem são determinados quando apenas o clima torna-se insuficiente para explicá-los.
Um modelo bidimensional espacialmente explícito foi desenvolvido para simulação
da dinâmica desses mosaicos de vegetação. O modelo inclui variações topográficas do
terreno, dispersão de sementes e propagação de fogo, incorporados a um modelo adaptativo
global de dinâmica de vegetação (2D-aDGVM). Processos biofísicos, fisiológicos e
demográficos são simulados sob influência de heterogeneidades espaciais (geradas por
variações topográficas na radiação solar incidente) associadas ao comportamento do fogo,
em passos de tempo diários. Mecanismos de retroalimentação (feedback) dependentes da
densidade de elementos arbóreos, produção primária de biomassa de gramíneas e
comportamento do fogo (intensidade, freqüência e propagação) foram avaliados em
diferentes escalas.
Os resultados indicaram um domínio das formações florestais sob o regime climático
atual. No entanto, a dinâmica dos mosaicos foi sensível às variações espaciais que
influenciaram os mecanismos de feedback avaliados e ao arranjo inicial das manchas de
vegetação na paisagem. Considerando um regime de fogo freqüente, uma co-dominância
estável entre campos e florestas só foi observada na ausência de heterogeneidades espaciais.
Na presença de heterogeneidades espaciais, a expansão florestal é mais rápida nas faces
voltadas para o sul do que naquelas voltadas para o norte. No entanto, quando considerado o
padrão mais agregado dos mosaicos observados, observou-se uma relativa estabilidade das
bordas, independentemente da topografia. A alternância de domínio entre campos e florestas
observada no passado, bem como a dependência de fatores internos controladores da
dinâmica do sistema, associada a uma dependência dos estados iniciais da paisagem,
evidenciam a presença de estados alternativos. O reconhecimento dos campos naturais como
estados alternativos na paisagem, e não como estados sucessionais, tem implicações
importantes nas decisões relacionadas ao manejo e à conservação da rica biodiversidade
dessas antigas formações vegetais.
abstract_english:
The factors and mechanisms that allow coexistence between grassland and
forest formations during periods with different dominant climatic regimes are not yet fully understood.

title_original: As causas ecológicas da especialização individual
title_english: The ecological causes of individual specialization
abstract_original: A teoria ecológica clássica foi construída sob a suposição de que os indivíduos de uma população são ecologicamente equivalentes, consumindo os mesmos recursos e interagindo com os mesmos competidores, predadores e parasitas. Existe, no entanto, crescente evidência empírica de que os indivíduos que formam populações naturais podem variar substancialmente em seus atributos ecológicos. Por exemplo, populações generalistas podem ser formadas por individuos especialistas, cujos nichos são pequenos subconjuntos do nicho populacional. Essa especialização individual’ já foi documentada em cerca de 180 espécies de vertebrados e invertebrados, o que indica ser este um fenômeno prevalente na natureza. Modelos ecológicos e evolutivos têm demonstrado que esta variação pode ter importantes consequências, como a geração de seleção natural disruptiva e a estabilização das dinâmicas ecológicas, facilitando a persistência e a coexistência das populações. Seus mecanismos ecológicos, no entanto, ainda são pouco compreendidos. A evidência empírica disponível parece confirmar previsões teóricas de que o grau de especialização individual depende da intensidade da competição intra- e interespecífica e da predação. A generalidade desses resultados, no entanto, ainda está por ser determinada, o que dependerá do acúmulo de estudos futuros”
abstract_english:
"Classical ecological theory was built on the assumption that individuals in a population are ecologically equivalent, consuming the same resources and interacting with the same competitors, predators, and parasites. There is, however, growing empirical evidence that individuals that form natural populations can vary substantially in their ecological attributes. For example, generalist populations may be made up of specialist individuals whose niches are small subsets of the population niche. This 'individual specialization' has been documented in about 180 vertebrate and invertebrate species, indicating that it is a prevalent phenomenon in nature. Ecological and evolutionary models have shown that this variation can have important consequences, such as the generation of disruptive natural selection and the stabilization of ecological dynamics, facilitating the persistence and coexistence of populations. Its ecological mechanisms, however, are still poorly understood. The available empirical evidence seems to confirm theoretical predictions that the degree of individual specialization depends on the intensity of intra- and interspecific competition and predation. The generality of these results, however, is yet to be determined, which will depend on the accumulation of future studies."
"

title_original: O papel do distúrbio na dinâmica da vegetação dos Campos Sulinos
title_english: The role of disturbance in the vegetation dynamics of the Campos Sulinos
abstract_original: Os Campos Sulinos são ecossistemas naturais únicos no Brasil, rico em espécies vegetais (ca. 3000 sp), fazendo parte de dois biomas brasileiros (Mata Atlântica e Pampa). Estão distribuídos nos três estados mais ao sul do Brasil e devido a sua localização, estes campos possuem uma rica diversidade de gramíneas C3 e C4, além de famílias e espécies típicas tanto dos trópicos como de áreas de clima temperado. Devido ao clima subtropical úmido, com chuvas bem distribuídas ao longo de todo ano, espera-se uma dominância de fisionomias florestais nestas áreas. Apesar disso, uma vegetação campestre rica em espécies é encontrada em diversas áreas, em contato ou não com floresta. Estes campos são então naturais ou resultado do desmatamento? Estudos paleopalinológicos mostraram que até o início do Holoceno a região era dominada por vegetação campestre. Posteriormente, devido a mudanças no clima (mais quente e mais úmido), a floresta começou a expandir sobre os Campos. Portanto, os Campos Sulinos estão presentes nestas áreas antes da expansão das florestas. Mas por que eles ainda estão presentes nesta região de clima propenso à expansão florestal? O distúrbio é provavelmente o fator mais importante para a manutenção da diversidade dos Campos Sulinos. Tanto o fogo como o pastejo influenciam a dinâmica da vegetação dos Campos. Atualmente, esta região não possui grandes herbívoros nativos e portanto, o gado é o animal pastejador mais importante da região e sua criação é uma importante atividade econômica da região. Além disso, o fogo é um fator que não deve ser ignorado, uma vez que ele está presente nesta vegetação há pelo menos desde o Holoceno e é utilizado até hoje pela população local, apesar do seu uso ser proibido por lei. Portanto, o objetivo principal deste seminário é apresentar aspectos importantes pouco conhecidos da dinâmica dos Campos Sulinos, mostrando a importância principalmente do distúrbio na sua biodiversidade, dinâmica e conservação.
abstract_english: The Campos Sulinos are unique natural ecosystems in Brazil, rich in plant species (ca. 3000 sp), and are part of two Brazilian biomes (Mata Atlântica and Pampa). They are distributed in the three southernmost states of Brazil and due to their location, these fields have a rich diversity of C3 and C4 grasses, as well as families and species typical of both the tropics and temperate climate areas. Due to the humid subtropical climate, with well distributed rainfall throughout the year, a dominance of forest physiognomies is expected in these areas. Nevertheless, a species-rich grassland vegetation is found in many areas, in contact or not with the forest. Are these grasslands therefore natural or the result of deforestation? Paleopalinological studies have shown that until the beginning of the Holocene the region was dominated by grassland vegetation. Later, due to changes in the climate (warmer and more humid), the forest started to expand over the grasslands. Therefore, the Campos Sulinos are present in these areas before the expansion of the forests. But why are they still present in this region with a climate that is prone to forest expansion? Disturbance is probably the most important factor in maintaining the diversity of the Campos Sulinos. Both fire and grazing influence the dynamics of the grasslands' vegetation. Currently, this region has no large native herbivores and therefore cattle are the most important grazing animal in the region and cattle breeding is an important economic activity in the region. Furthermore, fire is a factor that should not be ignored, since it has been present in this vegetation since at least the Holocene and is used until today by the local population, despite its use being prohibited by law. Therefore, the main objective of this seminar is to present important little known aspects of the dynamics of the Campos Sulinos, showing the importance mainly of disturbance in its biodiversity, dynamics and conservation.

title_original: Stable isotope enrichment in laboratory fire ant colonies: fat storage, metamorphosis and diet effects
title_english: Stable isotope enrichment in laboratory fire ant colonies: fat storage, metamorphosis and diet effects
abstract_original: Carbon and nitrogen isotope ratios have been used to determine trophic levels. Generally, 1‰ and a 3‰ carbon and nitrogen enrichment is expected in organisms in relation to their diet. However, diet quality, starvation, percentage fat, and other physiological factors influence isotopic values. We used laboratory-reared fire ant (Solenopsis invicta Buren, Formicidae) colonies to test the effects of fat body lipid storage, metamorphosis and diet on isotopic values. To test the effect of lipid extraction, workers were soaked for 10 days in ethanol and hexane-isopropanol. Impacts of metamorphosis on isotope values were studied in colonies maintained with crickets and sugar water. The diet effect was tested over in colonies that received additionally tuna fish. Lipid extraction produced enriched nitrogen isotope values, but had no effect on δ13C values. Fat storage varied temporally in fire ants; larvae, pupae and workers collected after 75 days of colony development were depleted in heavy carbon relative to larvae, pupae and workers collected after 15 days. Nitrogen enrichment was 1.11-1.4‰ when pupae molted to workers in colonies fed with cricket and sugar water. Colonies fed with tuna also showed nitrogen enrichment, but molting effect from pupae to workers was 0.49-0.78‰ less. Stable isotopes are useful in the study of insect diets, but carbon and nitrogen enrichment levels should be evaluated first in laboratory colonies whenever possible. Isotopic values should be interpreted carefully in holometabolous insects that also have fat storage temporal variation.
abstract_english: Carbon and nitrogen isotope ratios have been used to determine trophic levels. Generally, 1‰ and a 3‰ carbon and nitrogen enrichment is expected in organisms in relation to their diet. However, diet quality, starvation, percentage fat, and other physiological factors influence isotopic values. We used laboratory-reared fire ant (Solenopsis invicta Buren, Formicidae) colonies to test the effects of fat body lipid storage, metamorphosis and diet on isotopic values. To test the effect of lipid extraction, workers were soaked for 10 days in ethanol and hexane-isopropanol. Impacts of metamorphosis on isotope values were studied in colonies maintained with crickets and sugar water. The diet effect was tested over in colonies that received additionally tuna fish. Lipid extraction produced enriched nitrogen isotope values, but had no effect on δ13C values. Fat storage varied temporally in fire ants; larvae, pupae and workers collected after 75 days of colony development were depleted in heavy carbon relative to larvae, pupae and workers collected after 15 days. Nitrogen enrichment was 1.11-1.4‰ when pupae molted to workers in colonies fed with cricket and sugar water. Colonies fed with tuna also showed nitrogen enrichment, but molting effect from pupae to workers was 0.49-0.78‰ less. Stable isotopes are useful in the study of insect diets, but carbon and nitrogen enrichment levels should be evaluated first in laboratory colonies whenever possible. Isotopic values should be interpreted carefully in holometabolous insects that also have fat storage temporal variation.

title_original: Sistemas radiculares nos ecossistemas florestais tropicais
title_english: Root systems in tropical forest ecosystems
abstract_original: Após uma breve descrição dos aspectos conhecidos sobre a estrutura e o funcionamento dos sistemas radiculares nos ecossistemas florestais, a palestra apresentará alguns exemplos de estudos recentes no Brasil sobre este tema. O objetivo será mostrar quais são os tipos de estudos mais promissores sobre este tema que poderiam ser realizados. Alguns dos exemplos que serão apresentados são: (1) a dinâmica de crescimento em profundidade das raizes em plantações florestais, (2) o efeito das interações entre espécies sobre a exploração do solo (overyielding’ e niche partitioning’ hipoteses), (3) a capacidade de absorção de varios nutrientes em função da profundidade (avaliada por traçadores), e (4) a substituição de raizes finas são alguns exemplos que serão apresentados.
abstract_english: After a brief description of the known aspects about the structure and function of root systems in forest ecosystems, the lecture will present some examples of recent studies in Brazil on this subject. The objective will be to show which are the most promising types of studies on this subject that could be carried out. Some of the examples that will be presented are: (1) the dynamics of root growth at depth in forest plantations, (2) the effect of species interactions on soil exploitation (overyielding' and niche partitioning' hypotheses), (3) the absorption capacity of various nutrients as a function of depth (evaluated by tracers), and (4) the replacement of fine roots are some examples that will be presented.

title_original: A complexidade está nos olhos de quem vê
title_english: Complexity is in the eye of the beholder
abstract_original: A incrível diversidade de espécies em florestas tropicais sempre fez crer que esses eram ecossistemas extremamente complexos. A análise das estratégias ecológicas dessas espécies, no entanto, pode revelar padrões de diversidade bem mais simples. Caracterizando as principais espécies de árvore da Floresta Amazônica, descobrimos que a maioria delas adota apenas dois tipos básicos de estratégia (TE), os quais são responsáveis por mais da metade da biomassa vegetal dessa floresta, configurando uma grande dominância ecológica. Dado que praticamente não há dominância entre as espécies, a concentração de biomassa em dois TE pode ser explicada pelo grande número de espécies que adotam esses dois TE, provavelmente como resultado de processos evolutivos que geraram muitas espécies com estratégias ecológicas semelhantes. Entender como surgiram padrões tão distintos de diversidade de espécies e de estratégias pode fornecer pistas valiosas para compreendermos como ecossistemas tão ricos e produtivos se mantém.
abstract_english: The incredible diversity of species in tropical forests has always led one to believe that they are extremely complex ecosystems. Analyzing the ecological strategies of these species, however, can reveal much simpler patterns of diversity. Characterizing the major tree species of the Amazon rainforest, we found that most of them adopt only two basic types of strategy (TE), which account for more than half of the vegetation biomass of this forest, configuring a great ecological dominance. Since there is practically no dominance among species, the concentration of biomass in two TE can be explained by the large number of species that adopt these two TE, probably as a result of evolutionary processes that generated many species with similar ecological strategies. Understanding how such distinct patterns of species diversity and strategies arose can provide valuable clues to understanding how such rich and productive ecosystems are maintained.

title_original: Mothers matter - How maternal investment can help offspring to cope with environmental stress
title_english: Mothers matter - How maternal investment can help offspring to cope with environmental stress
abstract_original: Environmental stress can considerably reduce an organism’s reproductive success and survival prospect. Although environmental stress has always been a component of the natural environment of living organisms, the stressors that they are currently exposed to are larger than ever before due to the expansion of human population and the increasing impact of man on its surroundings. Yet, organisms have several mechanisms at their disposal to buffer the impact of environmental stress. I studied whether an adjustment of maternal investment is such a mechanism. More specifically, I investigated whether mothers adjust their investment in eggs in response to environmental stress and whether maternal investment affects offspring phenotype. To that purpose, I manipulated parasite abundance in nests of great tits (Parus major), a common European bird species, and studied effects on several egg components and offspring traits. Results will be presented and discussed within the framework of environmental stress coping
abstract_english: Environmental stress can considerably reduce an organism’s reproductive success and survival prospect. Although environmental stress has always been a component of the natural environment of living organisms, the stressors that they are currently exposed to are larger than ever before due to the expansion of human population and the increasing impact of man on its surroundings. Yet, organisms have several mechanisms at their disposal to buffer the impact of environmental stress. I studied whether an adjustment of maternal investment is such a mechanism. More specifically, I investigated whether mothers adjust their investment in eggs in response to environmental stress and whether maternal investment affects offspring phenotype. To that purpose, I manipulated parasite abundance in nests of great tits (Parus major), a common European bird species, and studied effects on several egg components and offspring traits. Results will be presented and discussed within the framework of environmental stress coping

title_original: Ecologia comportamental e escolha de planta hospedeira em insetos herbívoros: O efeito de formigas nas decisões de borboletas
title_english: Behavioral ecology and host plant choice in herbivorous insects: The effect of ants on butterfly decisions
abstract_original:
A capacidade de fazer decisões apropriadas ao selecionar a planta hospedeira é uma característica comportamental importante em insetos herbívoros. Uma vez que inimigos naturais são abundantes na folhagem, herbívoros enfrentam um dilema crítico: ao colonizar uma planta, é necessário encontrar um local seguro para a prole. Obter informações relacionadas a riscos ou benefícios à prole torna-se, então, crucial antes da oviposição numa dada planta. Espera-se que a seleção natural favoreça a habilidade em fêmeas de selecionar locais na folhagem que aumentem a sobrevivência da prole.
Formigas são organismos dominantes na vegetação. Esta supremacia, adicionada ao fato de muitas espécies serem agressivas, faz com que formigas afetem marcadamente a vida de insetos herbívoros – para o mal e para o bem.
Experimentos no cerrado demonstram que relações antagônicas ou mutualísticas entre formigas e a prole larval de borboletas representam pressões seletivas relevantes mediando decisões de colonização em borboletas adultas.
abstract_english:
The ability to make appropriate decisions when selecting a host plant is an important behavioral trait in herbivorous insects. Since natural enemies are abundant in foliage, herbivores face a critical dilemma: when colonizing a plant, it is necessary to find a safe place for the offspring. Obtaining information related to risks or benefits to the offspring then becomes crucial prior to oviposition on a given plant. Natural selection is expected to favor the ability in females to select sites in the foliage that enhance offspring survival.
Ants are dominant organisms in vegetation. This supremacy, added to the fact that many species are aggressive, means that ants markedly affect the lives of herbivorous insects - for better or worse.
Experiments in the cerrado demonstrate that antagonistic or mutualistic relationships between ants and the larval offspring of butterflies represent relevant selective pressures mediating colonization decisions in adult butterflies.

title_original: Desvendando a influência da perda de habitat sobre a composição da comunidade e extinção de espécies
title_english: Unraveling the influence of habitat loss on community composition and species extinction
abstract_original: A perda de habitat é uma das principais ameaças à biodiversidade, no entanto nossa capacidade de prevenir uma provável extinção em massa é dificultada pela falta de um embasamento teórico que leve em consideração a complexidade espacial de paisagens fragmentadas. Este estudo teve como objetivo gerar predições teóricas quantitativas que possam complementar nosso entendimento de como a composição da comunidade e extinção de espécies são influenciadas pela perda de habitat. Nós simulamos mais de 6 milhões de comunidades estruturadas pela relação espécie-área, em múltiplas escalas espaciais e com diferentes magnitudes, e comparamos os padrões obtidos com aqueles apresentados por uma comunidade de aves da Mata Atlântica, em que mais de 7000 indivíduos foram capturados em 65 fragmentos de seis paisagens. Nós encontramos que os padrões observados na comunidade de aves da Mata Atlântica são mais semelhantes aos de comunidades estruturadas por variações na composição da comunidade ao longo do gradiente de perturbação, do que de comunidades estruturadas apenas pela relação espécie-área. Os resultados mostram que em comunidades que apresentam turnover” de espécies, a riqueza de espécies é fracamente correlacionada com as estimativas de extinção, e os valores de Z da relação espécie-área subestimam os efeitos da perda de habitat.
abstract_english: Habitat loss is one of the main threats to biodiversity, yet our ability to prevent a likely mass extinction is hampered by the lack of a theoretical foundation that takes into account the spatial complexity of fragmented landscapes. This study aimed to generate quantitative theoretical predictions that can complement our understanding of how community composition and species extinction are influenced by habitat loss. We simulated over 6 million communities structured by the species-area relationship, at multiple spatial scales and different magnitudes, and compared the patterns obtained with those presented by an Atlantic Forest bird community in which over 7000 individuals were captured in 65 fragments across six landscapes. We found that the patterns observed in the Atlantic Forest bird community are more similar to those of communities structured by variations in community composition along the disturbance gradient, than to communities structured only by the species-area relationship. The results show that in communities that exhibit species turnover, species richness is weakly correlated with extinction estimates, and Z values of the species-area relationship underestimate the effects of habitat loss.

title_original: Cronobiologia de roedores subterrâneos
title_english: Chronobiology of Subterranean Rodents
abstract_original: Será que animais que vivem em túneis subterrâneos, sem contato com os ciclos ambientais terrestres, apresentam ritmos de 24h? Uma vez que o ciclo claro/escuro da Terra é  considerado o principal sincronizador dos relógios biológicos, será que roedores subterrâneos se expõem à luz, em algum momento do dia? Essas perguntas representaram o ponto de partida para nosso estudo da Cronobiologia de tuco-tucos (Ctenomys cf.knighti), em centro de pesquisa localizado em pleno habitat natural, nos desertos argentinos. Estudos em campo da sincronização de relógios biológicos ainda são poucos e resolvemos abordar essas questões, de forma integrada, em campo e em laboratório. Fomos surpreendidos, em nossas observações, por uma série de peculiaridades comportamentais destes animais subterrâneos que, em conjunto, podem contribuir para o entendimento do paradoxo da atividade diurna demonstrada por diversas espécies de roedores noturnos, em campo.
abstract_english: Do animals living in underground tunnels, with no contact with terrestrial environmental cycles, exhibit 24-hour rhythms? Since the Earth's light/dark cycle is considered the main synchronizer of biological clocks, do underground rodents expose themselves to light at some point during the day? These questions represented the starting point for our study of the chronobiology of tuco-tucos (Ctenomys cf. knighti) at a research center located in the middle of the natural habitat in the Argentinean deserts. Field studies on the synchronization of biological clocks are still scarce and we decided to address these issues, in an integrated manner, in the field and in the laboratory. We were surprised, in our observations, by a series of behavioral peculiarities of these subterranean animals that, together, may contribute to the understanding of the paradox of daytime activity demonstrated by several species of nocturnal rodents in the field.

title_original: From animal movement to population dynamics: living (or dying) in fragmented landscapes
title_english: From animal movement to population dynamics: living (or dying) in fragmented landscapes
abstract_original: The analysis of animal movement is challenging as empirical data depend on an interaction between the individuals movement propensity and the structure of the environment. Further, with many data types such as mark-release-recapture, it can be difficult to separate the influence of the study design from the biological signal. I show how Bayesian state-space models can be used to disentangle these confounding factors, using diffusion-based models and mark-recapture data on butterflies as the main example. I scale up from individual movements to population dynamics using the long-term study of the Glanville fritillary butterfly (by Ilkka Hanski) as a case study. I synthesize the results from case studies to discuss how the long-term persistence of species in fragmented landscapes depends on the interplay between the properties of the species and the structure of the environment.
abstract_english: The analysis of animal movement is challenging as empirical data depend on an interaction between the individuals movement propensity and the structure of the environment. Further, with many data types such as mark-release-recapture, it can be difficult to separate the influence of the study design from the biological signal. I show how Bayesian state-space models can be used to disentangle these confounding factors, using diffusion-based models and mark-recapture data on butterflies as the main example. I scale up from individual movements to population dynamics using the long-term study of the Glanville fritillary butterfly (by Ilkka Hanski) as a case study. I synthesize the results from case studies to discuss how the long-term persistence of species in fragmented landscapes depends on the interplay between the properties of the species and the structure of the environment.
