formigas. Havia, entretanto, uma importante lacuna a ser preenchida: a de estudos que efetivamente
descrevessem o comportamento de opiliões quando confrontados com seus potenciais predadores.
Realizamos, então, alguns estudos nesta área e, para nossa surpresa, a emissão de secreções
defensivas parece não ser tão comum ao menos contra aranhas. Mostrarei experimentos que testam
uma hipótese previamente ignorada na literatura: a de que a cutícula espessa que reveste o corpo da
maior parte das espécies da ordem é uma eficiente forma de defesa. Os dados que mostrarei nessa
palestra sugerem que, também em aracnídeos, parece ter evoluído um tegumento espesso que
protege contra predadores, assim como nos besouros entre os insetos, nas tartarugas entre os répteis
ou em tatus e pangolins entre os mamíferos. A defesa química nos opiliões talvez seja mais utilizada
contra outros predadores, como alguns vertebrados.
abstract_english:
Opilions are arachnids known for the strong odor that some species can emit through
a pair of defense glands that open latero-dorsally. Historically, studies in the area
typically described the defensive secretion chemically, the mode of release by manipulation with
manipulation with tweezers, and tested the effect of the isolated secretion against predators, mainly ants.
ants. There was, however, an important gap to be filled: studies that effectively described the
describe the behavior of opilions when confronted with potential predators.
We conducted some studies in this area and, to our surprise, the emission of defensive secretions seems not to be so common.
seems to be not so common at least against spiders. I will show you experiments that test
hypothesis previously ignored in the literature: that the thick cuticle that covers the body of most species in the
most species of the order is an efficient form of defense. The data that I will show in this
suggest that, also in arachnids, a thick integument seems to have evolved that
against predators, as in beetles among insects, turtles among reptiles, or armadillos and pangolins among reptiles.
or in armadillos and pangolins among mammals. The chemical defense in opilions may be more used against other predators
against other predators, such as some vertebrates.

title_original: Integração de fenótipos e ecologia durante a evolução do morfotipo serpentiforme
title_english: Integration of phenotypes and ecology during the evolution of the serpentiform morphotype
abstract_original: Bem por medo ou fascinação, o grupo das serpentes deixa poucas pessoas indiferentes, existindo muitas teorias sobre sua origem. Estudar a evolucão do morfotipo serpentiforme a partir dos lagartos permite entender como fenótipos de diferentes categorias (morfologia, fisiologia, comportamento) interagem entre si e com o ambiente durante processos macroevolutivos de transformação. Na palestra, veremos um pouco de como isto aconteceu nos pequenos e coloridos lagartos Gymnopthalmini, habitantes das areias da Caatinga.
abstract_english: Well out of fear or fascination, the group of snakes leaves few people indifferent, and there are many theories about their origin. Studying the evolution of the serpentiform morphotype from lizards allows us to understand how phenotypes of different categories (morphology, physiology, behavior) interact with each other and with the environment during macroevolutionary processes of transformation. In the talk, we will see some of how this happened in the small and colorful Gymnopthalmini lizards, inhabitants of the sands of the Caatinga.

title_original: Stability in community functioning despite tropical forest loss?
title_english: Stability in community functioning despite tropical forest loss?
abstract_original:
Habitat loss is one of the major conservation issues worldwide, because it has large negative
effects on biodiversity. Yet other implications, such as the consequences for ecosystem
functioning, remain poorly explored. I examined the effects of habitat loss from a functional point
of view using a dataset of 137 bird species that were captured in more than 50 sites in the Brazilian
Atlantic Forest, encompassing a large range of forest cover. More specifically, I tested the
predictions that forest cover is positively associated with metrics of functional diversity and
community integrity, and with the proportion of specialist species in the community. Results
indicate that habitat loss indeed leads to functionally less integer communities, mostly because of
a loss of specialists. On the contrary, functional diversity metrics showed heterogeneous
relationships with forest cover, suggesting a shift in rather than a loss of functional diversity. This
may indicate that community functioning is still fairly well preserved, despite large-scale habitat
destruction. I will discuss the possible consequences of these findings for species persistence in the

Atlantic forest.
abstract_english:
Habitat loss is one of the major conservation issues worldwide, because it has large negative
effects on biodiversity. Yet other implications, such as the consequences for ecosystem
functioning, remain poorly explored. I examined the effects of habitat loss from a functional point
of view using a dataset of 137 bird species that were captured in more than 50 sites in the Brazilian
Atlantic Forest, encompassing a large range of forest cover. More specifically, I tested the
predictions that forest cover is positively associated with metrics of functional diversity and
community integrity, and with the proportion of specialist species in the community. Results
indicate that habitat loss indeed leads to functionally less integer communities, mostly because of
a loss of specialists. On the contrary, functional diversity metrics showed heterogeneous
relationships with forest cover, suggesting a shift in rather than a loss of functional diversity. This
may indicate that community functioning is still fairly well preserved, despite large-scale habitat
destruction. I will discuss the possible consequences of these findings for species persistence in the

Atlantic forest.

title_original: Respostas da biodiversidade e florestas dentro de áreas protegidas com habitantes humanos quando as florestas do entorno são eliminadas
title_english: Responses of biodiversity and forests within protected areas with human inhabitants when surrounding forests are eliminated
abstract_original: O que acontece com diversidade, distribuição e abundância de animais em áreas protegidas quando o entorno é desmatado? O que acontece com cobertura florestal e os meios de vida de habitantes de áreas protegidas quando as terras do entorno são transformadas em plantios de soja ou inundadas por hidrelétricas? O que acontece com os habitantes humanos quando as populações crescem, quando a mortalidade infantil diminui por conta de melhorias nos serviços de saúde ou quando essa população recebe suplementos alimentares externos, tal como ocorre quando há acesso a programas como o Bolsa Verde ou Bolsa Floresta? Exploramos as respostas para estas perguntas utilizando um programa de simulações desenvolvido por nosso grupo de pesquisa. Este programa usa um exemplo de um povo indígena e seu território, a partir de modelo validado com conjuntos extensos de dados de campo, e permite examinar como os fatores citados afetam o ambiente e meios de vida, isoladamente e em sinergia quando há interação dos fatores. O modelo também considera retroalimentação (feedback) entre todas as variáveis, e representa um ferramenta de grande potencial para os interessados em terra, biodiversidade e manejo florestal em áreas naturais com habitantes humanos.
abstract_english: What happens to the diversity, distribution and abundance of animals in protected areas when the surrounding area is deforested? What happens to forest cover and the livelihoods of protected area inhabitants when surrounding lands are turned into soybean plantations or flooded by hydroelectric dams? What happens to human inhabitants when populations grow, when infant mortality decreases because of improved health services, or when this population receives external food supplements, such as when there is access to programs like Bolsa Verde or Bolsa Floresta? We explore the answers to these questions using a simulation program developed by our research group. This program uses an example of an indigenous people and its territory, from a model validated with extensive field data sets, and allows us to examine how the cited factors affect the environment and livelihoods, in isolation and in synergy when the factors interact. The model also considers feedback between all variables, and represents a tool of great potential for those interested in land, biodiversity and forest management in natural areas with human inhabitants.

title_original: Planejamento de expedições científicas em áreas remotas: Você, ou sua equipe de pesquisa, é autossuficiente caso esteja entregue à própria sorte e competência em alguma área remota?
title_english: Planning scientific expeditions in remote areas: Are you or your research team self-sufficient if you are left to your own devices and competence in a remote area?
abstract_original:
Atividades de pesquisas em áreas remotas são inerentemente arriscadas, por isso, preparar os
participantes de uma equipe para lidar com riscos é tão importante quanto qualquer outra etapa do
planejamento de um projeto de pesquisa. Trabalhos de campo em áreas remotas, principalmente em
consultorias científicas, requerem treinamentos que envolvem desde procedimentos de emergência até
gestão de segurança (e.g. avaliação de riscos, tomada de decisão em situações difíceis, segurança e
supervisão de grupos). Entretanto, estes e outros temas são, em geral, negligenciados por biólogos, desde
sua formação na graduação até à atuação profissional. Essa conduta pode comprometer não só o trabalho
de campo como também, ter consequências graves, e muitas vezes irreversíveis.
Esta palestra é destinada a estudantes e profissionais, principalmente na área de biologia, que
desenvolvem trabalho de campo em áreas remotas (ou em condições remotas). Seu principal objetivo é
compartilhar experiências, promover a reflexão e a discussão de temas relacionados a planejamento e
gestão de riscos com o intuito de demonstrar que segurança é uma mentalidade que deve permear todo o
projeto de pesquisa de modo a manter as pessoas focadas em momentos difíceis. Aprender a manejar
riscos é parte essencial do processo de planejamento de um projeto e, principalmente da autossegurança.
abstract_english:
Research activities in remote areas are inherently risky, so preparing team
team participants to deal with risk is as important as any other step in planning a research project.
planning a research project. Fieldwork in remote areas, especially in scientific
scientific consultancies, require training ranging from emergency procedures to safety management
safety management (e.g. risk assessment, decision making in difficult situations, safety, and group supervision).
supervision). However, these and other topics are often neglected by biologists, from their
from their undergraduate training to their professional practice. This conduct can compromise not only field work, but also
field work, but can also have serious, and often irreversible, consequences.
This lecture is intended for students and professionals, mainly in the area of biology, who
develop field work in remote areas (or in remote conditions). Its main objective is to
share experiences, promote reflection and discussion of topics related to planning and risk management
management with the intention of demonstrating that safety is a mentality that must permeate the entire research project
research project in order to keep people focused in difficult moments. Learning to manage
risks is an essential part of the planning process of a project, and especially self-safety.

title_original: Mecanismos de transferência de espermatozoides em cefalópodes: um modelo para estudos sobre convergências evolutivas e seleção sexual no ambiente marinho
title_english: Mechanisms of sperm transfer in cephalopods: a model for studies on evolutionary convergences and sexual selection in the marine environment
abstract_original: Cefalópodes estão dentre os mais belos e fascinantes de todos os invertebrados, devido à impressionante capacidade de mudança instantânea de cor e também aos sistemas nervoso e sensorial altamente desenvolvidos. Seu comportamento sexual é igualmente complexo, incluindo corte, combate entre machos e transferência indireta de espermatozoides por meio de espermatóforos que se fixam de forma autônoma na fêmea. Recentemente, os mecanismos de transferência de espermatozoides desses moluscos foram propostos como potencialmente convergentes e relacionados ao habitat. Por exemplo, a transferência de espermatóforos por meio de um apêndice do macho para um receptáculo especializado na fêmea é característica de cefalópodes costeiros e epi/mesopelágicos, enquanto a transferência pelo pênis de espermatóforos que são implantados externamente no corpo da fêmea é típica de espécies de águas profundas. A presença destas estratégias reprodutivas em linhagens distintas de Cephalopoda é considerada uma possível evidência de evolução convergente e de influência do habitat, embora estas hipóteses nunca tenham sido testadas em um contexto analítico formal. Tais testes são dificultados pela ausência de uma hipótese filogenética robusta para o grupo, bem como pela deficiência generalizada acerca do conhecimento sobre a morfologia e a base funcional desses sistemas. Além disso, detemos arcabouço teórico e experimental insuficiente para inferir como operam os mecanismos de seleção sexual para ambas as estratégias. Embora a pressão da competição espermática aparente ser expressiva nos sistemas de acasalamento da maioria dos cefalópodes já investigados, algumas evidências sugerem que a limitação espermática seja significativa em ambientes de profundidade. Avanços nas técnicas de amostragem de organismos de águas profundas permitem vislumbrar excelentes perspectivas para estudos na área, mas somente uma abordagem comparativa e multidisciplinar poderá contribuir para a compreensão sobre a evolução dessas estratégias e, consequentemente, permitir a inferência de padrões, processos e fatores que influenciam a evolução e diversificação no ambiente marinho.
abstract_english: Cephalopods are among the most beautiful and fascinating of all invertebrates, due to their impressive capacity for instantaneous color change and also their highly developed nervous and sensory systems. Their sexual behavior is equally complex, including courtship, combat between males, and indirect sperm transfer via spermatophores that attach themselves autonomously to the female. Recently, the sperm transfer mechanisms of these mollusks have been proposed as potentially convergent and habitat-related. For example, the transfer of spermatophores via an appendage of the male to a specialized receptacle in the female is characteristic of coastal and epi/mesopelagic cephalopods, whereas the transfer via the penis of spermatophores that are externally implanted in the female's body is typical of deep-water species. The presence of these reproductive strategies in distinct Cephalopoda lineages is considered to be possible evidence of convergent evolution and habitat influence, although these hypotheses have never been tested in a formal analytical context. Such tests are hampered by the absence of a robust phylogenetic hypothesis for the group, as well as the general deficiency about the knowledge about the morphology and functional basis of these systems. In addition, we have insufficient theoretical and experimental framework to infer how the mechanisms of sexual selection operate for both strategies. Although the pressure of sperm competition appears to be significant in the mating systems of most cephalopods already investigated, some evidence suggests that sperm limitation is significant in deep-sea environments. Advances in sampling techniques of deep-sea organisms allow glimpsing excellent prospects for studies in the area, but only a comparative and multidisciplinary approach can contribute to the understanding about the evolution of these strategies and, consequently, allow inference of patterns, processes and factors that influence evolution and diversification in the marine environment.

title_original: Uso da paleoecologia no entendimento dos ecossistemas de hoje
title_english: Using paleoecology to understand todays ecosystems
abstract_original:
A paleo-ecologia mostra os processos de dinâmica das
espécies a longo prazo. Apesar de ser uma disciplina

pouco desenvolvida no Brasil os resultados da paleo-
ecologia são muito citados pelos biólogos para explicar

fragmentação, expansão, extinção, especiação, a
distribuição que nos observamos hoje. Essa apresentação
tem o objetivo de rever alguns cliches e expor os
resultados mais recentes da paleo-ecologia no Brasil em
termos de métodos e de evolução dos ecossistemas.
abstract_english:
Paleoecology shows the processes of species dynamics
dynamics of species over the long term. Despite being a discipline that is

little developed in Brazil, the results of paleo
ecology are often cited by biologists to explain

fragmentation, expansion, extinction, speciation and the distribution
the distribution that we observe today. This presentation
presentation aims to review some clichés and expose the most recent
the most recent results of paleoecology in Brazil in terms of methods
terms of methods and ecosystem evolution.

title_original: Relações entre espécies crípticas do complexo fraterculus: uma narrativa multidisciplinar
title_english: Relations between cryptic species of the fraterculus complex: a multidisciplinary narrative
abstract_original:
As moscas-das-frutas (Tephritidae) utilizam a polpa ou semente de frutos como alimento no estágio
de larva. Quando os frutos são de valor comercial adquirem o status de inseto-praga, causando perdas diretas
ou indidretas da ordem de milhões de dólares anuais.O gênero Anastrepha é endêmico da região
Neotropical com cerca de 100 espécies, ocorrendo no Brasil. Dentre os 21 grupos taxonômicos
infragenéricos, destaca-se o grupo fraterculus, por sua importância econômica e dentro dele, o complexo de
espécies crípticas Anastrepha fraterculus. A discussão sobre esse complexo remonta a 1942, quando
reconheceu-se uma extensa variação morfológica nas asas, a qual foi atribuída à existência de raças
geográficas. Posteriormente, foram registradas variações em marcadores cromossômicos, moleculares e na
utilização de frutos hospedeiros que reforçaram a idéia de que um complexo de espécies deveria estar
envolvido nessa espécie nominal. A sua importância econômica, aliada ao fato de insetos fitófagos serem
excelentes modelos para estudos evolutivos motivaram os inúmeros estudos já realizados com essas moscas.
Após correlacionarmos marcadores moleculares, cromossômicos e morfológicos reconhecemos
descontinuidades genéticas promovidas por fatores redutores de fluxo gênico (comportamentais, ambientais
e epigenéticos) e com essa estratégia caracterizamos três entidades biológicas distintas do complexo, no
Brasil. A eficiência dessa abordagem multidisciplinar desencadeou um consórcio internacional, de âmbito
mundial, envolvendo países de quatro continentes para o estudo de complexos de espécies crípticas em
moscas-das-frutas. A caracterização das espécies é fundamental para o desenvolvimento de medidas de
controle populacional que minimizem a utilização de agrotóxicos. Atualmente, há consenso no
reconhecimento de pelo menos sete morfotipos do complexo A. fraterculus, na região Neotropical.
abstract_english:
Fruit flies (Tephritidae) use the pulp or seeds of fruits as food in the larval stage.
larval stage. When the fruits are of commercial value they acquire the status of pest insect, causing direct or indirect losses of millions of dollars annually.
The genus Anastrepha is endemic to the Neotropical region, with about 100 species of
The genus Anastrepha is endemic to the Neotropical region with about 100 species, occurring in Brazil. Among the 21 infrageneric taxonomic
fraterculus group stands out, due to its economic importance and within it, the complex of cryptic
Anastrepha fraterculus. The discussion about this complex dates back to 1942, when
recognized an extensive morphological variation in the wings, which was attributed to the existence of geographical races.
geographical races. Subsequently, variations in chromosomal and molecular markers and in host fruit
later, variations in chromosomal and molecular markers and in host fruit utilization were recorded, which reinforced the idea that a species complex must be involved in this nominal species.
involved in this nominal species. Its economic importance, together with the fact that phytophagous insects are excellent models for
The economic importance of these flies, together with the fact that phytophagous insects are excellent models for evolutionary studies, motivated the numerous studies already carried out with these flies.
After correlating molecular, chromosomal and morphological markers we recognize
genetic discontinuities promoted by factors that reduce gene flow (behavioral, environmental and epigenetic).
and epigenetic factors) and with this strategy we characterized three distinct biological entities of the complex in Brazil.
Brazil. The efficiency of this multidisciplinary approach has triggered a worldwide international consortium involving
countries from four continents to study cryptic species complexes in fruit flies.
fruit flies. The characterization of the species is fundamental for the development of
control measures that minimize the use of agrochemicals. Currently, there is consensus that
recognition of at least seven morphotypes of the A. fraterculus complex, in the Neotropical region.

title_original: Cores do engodo: evolução de sinais de alarme e mimetismo em espécies de cobra falsa coral (Colubroidea: Dipsadidae)
title_english: Decoy colors: evolution of alarm signals and mimicry in false coral snake species (Colubroidea: Dipsadidae)
abstract_original: Espécies de cobra-coral são reconhecidas pelo seu colorido contrastante, potência do veneno e por formarem um complexo mimético de corais falsas e verdadeiras. As corais verdadeiras são espécies pertencentes à família Elapidae enquanto que parte das espécies de corais falsas estão concentradas na família Dipsadidae. Dipsadidae apresenta cerca de 600 espécies distribuídas nas Américas e Índias Ocidentais. Por um longo tempo encontra-se na literatura a hipótese de que espécies de Elapidae são modelos mimetizados pelos dipsadídeos. No entanto, existem trabalhos que apontam que a relação mimética pode ser invertida, com o principal argumento de que a potência do veneno das corais verdadeiras não permite associação por aprendizado. Outros questionam a existência de um complexo mimético e apontam que a semelhança de coloração seria resultado de convergência dos grupos na mesma estratégia de defesa. Até o momento, evidências disponíveis na literatura são restritas à semelhança fenotípica, co-ocorrência das espécies e associação do padrão de coloração com diminuição na frequência de predação. Neste trabalho buscamos entender os padrões de evolução da coloração das espécies de Dipsadidae e avaliar uma possível associação do fenótipo com diferentes taxas de acumulo de espécies no grupo. Nós utilizamos dados disponíveis na literatura e em repositórios digitais para reconstruir as relações de parentesco do grupo e classificar as espécies em seus respectivos padrões de coloração. Utilizamos modelos de evolução para estimar parâmetros de extinção e especiação dependente da presença dos padrões de cores (modelos BiSSE). Encontramos que linhagens que apresentam coloração semelhante às espécies de corais verdadeiras possuem taxas de diversificação pelo menos duas vezes maiores do que espécies com padrões crípticos. A reconstrução filogenética indica dois momentos independentes na evolução do grupo em que a perda da coloração mimética está associada à ausência de espécies de coral verdadeira na região e com mudanças no comportamento defensivo das espécies de coral falsa. Tanto análises macroevolutivas quanto dados de distribuição geográfica, uso do habitat e comportamento reforçam a ideia de um complexo mimético entre espécies de coral verdadeira (Elapidae) e coral falsa (Dipsadidae) na região Neotropical.
abstract_english: Coral snake species are recognized by their contrasting coloring, venom potency and by forming a mimetic complex of false and true corals. The true corals are species belonging to the family Elapidae while part of the false coral species are concentrated in the family Dipsadidae. Dipsadidae has about 600 species distributed in the Americas and West Indies. For a long time it has been hypothesized in the literature that species of Elapidae are models mimicked by dipsadids. However, there are papers that point out that the mimetic relationship may be reversed, with the main argument that the potency of the venom of true corals does not allow association by learning. Others question the existence of a mimetic complex and point out that the similarity in coloration would be the result of convergence of the groups in the same defense strategy. So far, available evidence in the literature is restricted to phenotypic similarity, co-occurrence of the species, and association of coloration pattern with decreased predation frequency. In this work we sought to understand the patterns of coloration evolution in Dipsadidae species and to evaluate a possible association of the phenotype with different rates of species accumulation in the group. We used data available in the literature and in digital repositories to reconstruct the kinship relationships of the group and classify the species into their respective coloration patterns. We used evolutionary models to estimate parameters of extinction and speciation dependent on the presence of the color patterns (BiSSE models). We find that lineages that exhibit coloration similar to true coral species have diversification rates at least twice as high as species with cryptic patterns. Phylogenetic reconstruction indicates two independent moments in the evolution of the group in which the loss of mimetic coloration is associated with the absence of true coral species in the region and with changes in the defensive behavior of false coral species. Both macroevolutionary analyses and data on geographic distribution, habitat use, and behavior reinforce the idea of a mimetic complex between true coral (Elapidae) and false coral (Dipsadidae) species in the Neotropical region.

title_original: Is Latin American science really on the rise? Cross-national patterns of productivity and collaboration by ecologists.
title_english: Is Latin American science really on the rise? Cross-national patterns of productivity and collaboration by ecologists.
abstract_original: Recent decades have seen important advances in the scientific output of developing countries.  Nevertheless, the production of scientific knowledge remains geographically and economically skewed, with far greater productivity by scientists in the United States, Europe, and Japan. This knowledge divide” is seen as a major impediment not only to the advancement of science in developing countries, but to broader efforts at economic and social development as well. We analyzed all articles published from 2001-2010 in the 50 ecological journals with the highest impact factors (N >12,000 articles), to compare the number of publications produced by authors based in each of 18 countries in Latin America, compare the rate of change in productivity of these countries with previous decades, and describe the structure of the co-authorship networks. We then followed this up with ana analysis of >2 million articles from fields ranging from Chemistry to Evolutionary Biology to determine how international collaboration influenced where articles were published and how much they were cited.
abstract_english: Recent decades have seen important advances in the scientific output of developing countries.  Nevertheless, the production of scientific knowledge remains geographically and economically skewed, with far greater productivity by scientists in the United States, Europe, and Japan. This knowledge divide” is seen as a major impediment not only to the advancement of science in developing countries, but to broader efforts at economic and social development as well. We analyzed all articles published from 2001-2010 in the 50 ecological journals with the highest impact factors (N >12,000 articles), to compare the number of publications produced by authors based in each of 18 countries in Latin America, compare the rate of change in productivity of these countries with previous decades, and describe the structure of the co-authorship networks. We then followed this up with ana analysis of >2 million articles from fields ranging from Chemistry to Evolutionary Biology to determine how international collaboration influenced where articles were published and how much they were cited.

title_original: Análise Geográfica Computadorizada na Estimativa de Qualidade de Habitat para Mamíferos de Médio e Grande Porte
title_english: Computerized Geographic Analysis in Estimating Habitat Quality for Medium and Large Mammals
abstract_original:
A busca por métodos rápidos e confiáveis que localizem áreas de valor ecológico para diferentes
grupos de animais tem despertado grande interesse nos dias de hoje. A metodologia
desenvolvida objetivou determinar a variação da qualidade dos habitats inseridos em um
remanescente de cerrado (2.098ha) no estado de São Paulo, utilizando análise geográfica
computadorizada. Em função das necessidades ambientais de cada espécie estudada, foram
selecionados critérios abióticos e bióticos que pudessem ser inseridos em um modelo de
tomada de decisão e que fossem capazes de influenciar a qualidade do habitat e inferir a
ocorrência de sete espécies de mamíferos: Myrmecophaga tridactyla - tamanduá-bandeira,
Tapirus terrestris - anta, Pecari tajacu - cateto, Mazama americana - veado mateiro, Eira barbara
- irara, Puma concolor - onça parda e Leopardus pardalis - jaguatirica.
abstract_english:
The search for fast and reliable methods that locate areas of ecological value for different
groups of animals has aroused great interest nowadays. The methodology
developed aimed to determine the variation in the quality of habitats within a cerrado
cerrado (2,098ha) in the state of São Paulo, using computerized geographic analysis.
computerized geographic analysis. In function of the environmental needs of each species studied, abiotic and biotic
selected abiotic and biotic criteria that could be inserted into a decision-making model
decision making model that could influence habitat quality and infer the occurrence of seven mammal species
occurrence of seven mammal species: Myrmecophaga tridactyla - giant anteater,
Tapirus terrestris - tapir, Pecari tajacu - collared peccary, Mazama americana - mule deer, Eira barbara irara
- irara, Puma concolor - jaguar and Leopardus pardalis - ocelot.

title_original: Produção de argumentos em textos científicos: contribuições de um curso de campo na formação de ecólogos
title_english: Argument production in scientific texts: contributions of a field course in the training of ecologists
abstract_original:
A argumentação é tema amplamente analisado no ensino de ciências, porém não temos muitas
informações de como o cientista é formado no que diz respeito à argumentação na produção de textos
científicos. Desenvolvemos uma ferramenta que permite extrair a estrutura argumentativa de um artigo
científico e analisamos uma disciplina de ecologia de campo para entender como os alunos argumentam
em textos científicos. A Ferramenta do Argumento Central (CAF) foi inspirada em ferramentas de análise
do raciocínio científico e análises da argumentação no ensino de ciências. Em CAF, o texto científico é
resumido em oito elementos: Pergunta, Hipótese, Suporte da Hipótese, Previsão, Suporte da Previsão,
Conclusão, Suporte da Conclusão e Contra-argumento. Cada elemento tem de um a três parâmetros que
guiam a análise dos elementos, podendo ser avaliados como insuficiente ou suficiente. Acompanhamos a
disciplina Ecologia da Mata Atlântica, lecionada como parte do programa de pós-graduação em Ecologia da
Universidade de São Paulo. A disciplina nos três anos de coleta de dados contou com aulas iniciais,
projetos realizados em grupo e projetos individuais que eram reportados em manuscritos científicos
desenvolvidos pelos alunos. As diferentes análises realizadas nesta tese nos levam a concluir que os
alunos são capazes de apresentar alguns dos elementos argumentativos do texto científico desde as
primeiras versões dos manuscritos desenvolvidos, mas que há elementos do argumento central do texto
que os alunos falham em apresentar mesmo após a realização do curso. Há estratégias bem sucedidas na
disciplina associadas aos elementos que apresentaram melhora durante o curso. Professores usam
estratégias didáticas que foram bem sucedidas para ensinar aos alunos alguns dos elementos. Estratégias
similares deveriam ser utilizadas para elementos para os quais não houve melhora mesmo após o curso.
abstract_english:
Argumentation is a topic widely analyzed in science education, but we do not have much
information about how the scientist is trained with regard to argumentation in the production of scientific
scientific texts. We developed a tool that allows us to extract the argumentative structure of a scientific article
and analyze a field ecology course to understand how students argue in scientific texts.
in scientific texts. The Central Argument Tool (CAF) was inspired by tools for analyzing
of scientific reasoning and analysis of argumentation in science education. In CAF, the scientific text is
summarized into eight elements: Question, Hypothesis, Support of Hypothesis, Prediction, Support of Prediction,
Conclusion, Support of Conclusion, and Counterargument. Each element has from one to three parameters that
guide the analysis of the elements, and can be evaluated as insufficient or sufficient. We follow the
Ecology of the Atlantic Forest, taught as part of the graduate program in Ecology at the University of São Paulo.
University of São Paulo. The course in the three years of data collection included initial classes,
group and individual projects that were reported in scientific manuscripts developed by the students.
developed by the students. The different analyses performed in this thesis lead us to conclude that the
students are able to present some of the argumentative elements of the scientific text since the
early versions of the manuscripts developed, but that there are elements of the central argument of the text
that students fail to present even after taking the course. There are successful strategies in the
discipline associated with the elements that showed improvement during the course. Teachers use
didactic strategies that were successful in teaching students some of the elements. Similar strategies
should be used for elements for which there was no improvement even after the course.

title_original: Evolução do balanço hídrico em anuros: relações espaciais e temporais
title_english: Evolution of water balance in anurans: spatial and temporal relationships
abstract_original: O padrão de riqueza global de espécies de anfíbios anuros mostra uma clara associação positiva com disponibilidade hídrica ambiental. Observa-se também uma concentração da temporada reprodutiva da maior parte das espécies na estação chuvosa. Estas associações espaciais e temporais vêm sendo interpretadas como um reflexo de características do balanço hídrico deste grupo, particularmente a baixa resistência cutânea à perda de água por evaporação. Entretanto, pouco se sabe efetivamente sobre a evolução do balanço hídrico e suas implicações ecológicas. Alguns interessantes padrões de variação interespecífica de diferentes aspectos do balanço hídrico, associados tanto às dinâmicas temporais de atividade reprodutiva quanto à ocorrência de espécies de anuros em diferentes biomas vêm sendo explorados em nosso laboratório, e estes padrões serão apresentados e discutidos
abstract_english: The pattern of overall species richness of amphibian amphibians shows a clear positive association with environmental water availability. It is also observed a concentration of the breeding season for most species in the rainy season. These spatial and temporal associations have been interpreted as a reflection of the water balance characteristics of this group, particularly the low cutaneous resistance to water loss by evaporation. However, little is effectively known about the evolution of the water balance and its ecological implications. Some interesting patterns of interspecific variation in different aspects of water balance, associated with both the temporal dynamics of reproductive activity and the occurrence of anuran species in different biomes have been explored in our laboratory, and these patterns will be presented and discussed.

title_original: Ecologia evolutiva de drosofilídeos: adaptações ao clima e evolução de interações ecológicas
title_english: Evolutionary ecology of drosophilids: adaptations to climate and evolution of ecological interactions
abstract_original:
Avanços recentes em biologia molecular e genômica trouxeram uma
oportunidade inédita de estudar a interface entre processos ecológicos,
evolutivos e genéticos para entender em detalhes as adaptações dos
organismos. Irei apresentar os resultados de alguns projetos recentes que
buscam entender as pressões ecológicas em ambientes naturais que
influenciam os padrões de variação no nível genômico e resultam em
mudanças adaptativas. Irei apresentar projetos que abordam adaptações a
fatores abióticos do ambiente, bem como adaptações causadas por
interações ecológicas. Esses estudos foram feitos com populações
naturais do modelo genético Drosophila melanogaster.
abstract_english:
Recent advances in molecular biology and genomics have brought an
unprecedented opportunity to study the interface between ecological
evolutionary and genetic processes to understand in detail the adaptations of
organisms. I will present the results of some recent projects that
ecological pressures in natural environments that influence patterns of variation in
that influence variation patterns at the genomic level and result in adaptive
adaptive changes. I will present projects that address adaptations to abiotic
abiotic factors of the environment, as well as adaptations caused by
ecological interactions. These studies have been done with natural populations of the
natural populations of the genetic model Drosophila melanogaster.

title_original: 1ª EcoEscola: Resultados e próximas ações (ou como organizar um curso de inverno em 364 dias!)
title_english: 1st EcoSchool: Results and next actions (or how to organize a winter course in 364 days!)
abstract_original: NA
abstract_english: NA

title_original: Macro e micro-evolução de características das plantas e a importância das interações ecológicas
title_english: Macro- and micro-evolution of plant traits and the importance of ecological interactions
abstract_original:
Muitas características das plantas estão diretamente relacionadas com a manutenção das interações
ecológicas com os animais, principalmente os insetos. Por exemplo, nectários florais e extraflorais,
glândulas e tricomas glandulares, e mesmo os estames das plantas disponibilizam algum tipo de
recurso energético-nutricional para os animais. Mesmo as folhas e ramos das plantas são recurso
para uma infinidade de herbívoros. Portanto, as secreções e estruturas das plantas podem ser o
recurso para o conjunto de animais em uma dada comunidade, e a evolução das características
dessas plantas, em diferentes escalas, pode estar relacionada diretamente com o consumo e
utilização de suas partes pelos animais. Nesta apresentação eu explorarei alguns dos aspectos
relacionados a evolução de características-recurso das plantas, em particular o néctar e os nectários
extraflorais, geralmente associados a visitação de formigas. Nesse sistema acredita-se que as
formigas visitem as plantas atraídas pelo néctar enquanto protejam as plantas frente os herbívoros.
No entanto, essa generalização poderia não ser o caso para todas as plantas e/ou espécies com tais
estruturas secretoras. Será explorado aqui os padrões de evolução dos nectários extraflorais na
escala das filogenias (entre espécies), e também as hipóteses adaptativas na escala das populações
dentro de uma mesma espécie focal. Ambas as escalas são complementares para o entendimento
dos mecanismos eco-evolutivos responsáveis pelas mudanças na variação fenotípica dos nectários
ao longo do tempo.
abstract_english:
Many plant characteristics are directly related to the maintenance of ecological interactions with animals
ecological interactions with animals, especially insects. For example, floral and extrafloral nectaries
glands and glandular trichomes, and even the stamens of plants provide some kind of
nutritional energy resource for animals. Even the leaves and branches of plants are a resource
for a multitude of herbivores. Therefore, plant secretions and structures can be the
for all animals in a given community, and the evolution of the characteristics of these
of these plants, at different scales, may be directly related to the consumption and
use of their parts by animals. In this presentation I will explore some of the aspects
resource characteristics of plants, in particular the nectar and the extrafloral nectaries

In this system it is believed that ants visit plants attracted by the nectar while protecting the plants from herbivores.
However, this generalization might not be the case for all plants and/or species with such secretory structures.
secretory structures. The patterns of evolution of extrafloral nectaries at the scale of phylogenies (among species) will be explored here.
phylogeny scale (between species), and also the adaptive hypotheses at the population scale within the same focal species.

over time.

title_original: The ecology of chemical defenses and aposematism in poison frogs
title_english: The ecology of chemical defenses and aposematism in poison frogs
abstract_original:
Chemical defenses are widespread among animals and represent complex
adaptations against predators, microbes, and/or parasites. Animals generally
synthesize chemical defenses, although some species acquire defenses from external
sources such as symbionts or the diet. Dietary sequestration involves the uptake,
accumulation, and storage of defensive chemicals (or chemical precursors) that were
originally present in other organisms. Animals that sequester defensive chemicals are
typically dependent on specific dietary sources, which can result in complex
ecological interactions and unique evolutionary relationships. The chemical
properties and biological occurrence of defensive chemicals that mediate these
trophic interactions among organisms are fundamental to understanding these
complex defensive adaptations. Among amphibians, poison frogs of the families
Bufonidae, Dendrobatidae, Eleutherodactylidae, Mantellidae, and Myobatrachidae
sequester lipophilic alkaloids from dietary arthropods. Some of these amphibians use
conspicuous coloration to warn predators of their chemical defenses, a phenomenon
known as aposematism. In this talk, Dr. Ralph Saporito will summarize his ongoing
research into the chemical ecology and aposematism of poison frogs.
abstract_english:
Chemical defenses are widespread among animals and represent complex
adaptations against predators, microbes, and/or parasites. Animals generally
synthesize chemical defenses, although some species acquire defenses from external
sources such as symbionts or the diet. Dietary sequestration involves the uptake,
accumulation, and storage of defensive chemicals (or chemical precursors) that were
originally present in other organisms. Animals that sequester defensive chemicals are
typically dependent on specific dietary sources, which can result in complex
ecological interactions and unique evolutionary relationships. The chemical
properties and biological occurrence of defensive chemicals that mediate these
trophic interactions among organisms are fundamental to understanding these
complex defensive adaptations. Among amphibians, poison frogs of the families
Bufonidae, Dendrobatidae, Eleutherodactylidae, Mantellidae, and Myobatrachidae
sequester lipophilic alkaloids from dietary arthropods. Some of these amphibians use

known as aposematism. In this talk, Dr. Ralph Saporito will summarize his ongoing
research into the chemical ecology and aposematism of poison frogs.

title_original: Dicromatismo sexual e regra de Rensch em pigmentação alar em libélulas do Novo Mundo
title_english: Sexual dichromatism and Renschs rule on wing pigmentation in New World dragonflies
abstract_original:
Sexual dimorphism, broadly defined as a difference in any trait between males and females,
can emerge as the result of different selective pressures acting more strongly on one sex rather
than the other. A wide range of animal taxa that display sexual size dimorphism exhibit an
allometric relationship in which the degree of sexual dimorphism increases with body size, a
pattern known as Rensch’s rule. Here, we investigated variation in wing pigmentation and body
size in 640 populations of 83 species of New World libellulid dragonflies (Anisoptera,
Libellulidae). First, we found that sexual dichromatism in wing pigmentation was consistent
with Rensch’s rule, as the major axis regression slope was significantly greater than one (β =
1.756, 95% CI: 1.469 to 2.138, n = 69). Second, we show that sexual size dimorphism (SSD) in
dragonflies is not different from unit, and there is little evidence of Rensch’s rule in SSD in the
group, as this relationship is isometric. Taken together, our results provide evidence, for the
first time, that a trait other than body size exhibits a pattern consistent with Rensch’s rule.
These findings suggest that wing pigmentation is possibly under sex-specific or sexually
antagonistic selection in species with marked male-biased sexual dichromatism.
abstract_english:
Sexual dimorphism, broadly defined as a difference in any trait between males and females,
can emerge as the result of different selective pressures acting more strongly on one sex rather
than the other. A wide range of animal taxa that display sexual size dimorphism exhibit an
allometric relationship in which the degree of sexual dimorphism increases with body size, a
pattern known as Rensch’s rule. Here, we investigated variation in wing pigmentation and body
size in 640 populations of 83 species of New World libellulid dragonflies (Anisoptera,
Libellulidae). First, we found that sexual dichromatism in wing pigmentation was consistent
with Rensch’s rule, as the major axis regression slope was significantly greater than one (β =
1.756, 95% CI: 1.469 to 2.138, n = 69). Second, we show that sexual size dimorphism (SSD) in
dragonflies is not different from unit, and there is little evidence of Rensch’s rule in SSD in the
group, as this relationship is isometric. Taken together, our results provide evidence, for the
first time, that a trait other than body size exhibits a pattern consistent with Rensch’s rule.
These findings suggest that wing pigmentation is possibly under sex-specific or sexually
antagonistic selection in species with marked male-biased sexual dichromatism.

title_original: Diversificação e convergência fenotípica em redes mutualísticas
title_english: Diversification and phenotypic convergence in mutualistic networks
abstract_original:
Mutualismos são interações que aumentam a aptidão dos indivíduos de diferentes espécies
envolvidos. Alguns mutualismos são caracterizados por alta diversidade local de espécies e
grande convergência fenotípica. Foi proposto que as pressões seletivas impostas por
mutualismos favoreceriam a diversificação e a convergência fenotípica. Localmente,
mutualismos formam redes de interações compostas por dezenas de espécies. O estudo sobre
como estas redes de interações se formam e modulam pressões seletivas pode fornecer
informações sobre os processos gerando alta diversidade e convergência em mutualismos.
Nós exploramos o papel de mutualismos na diversificação por meio de modelos baseados em
indivíduos. Os resultados indicam que a seleção estabilizadora imposta por mutualistas não
favorece a diversificação mas sim reduz a variância fenotípica populacional. Por
conseguinte, a grande diversidade observada em mutualismos deve estar associada a outros
processos ecológicos e evolutivos. Nós usamos a combinação de modelos evolutivos e uma
abordagem analítica baseada na teoria de fluxo em redes complexas para mostrar como o
surgimento de convergência fenotípica está intimamente associado a forma como as espécies
interagem nessas redes, favorecendo efeitos evolutivos indiretos. De forma mais geral esses
resultados sugerem que a organização de redes mutualísticas pode ser importante para a
compreensão das consequências evolutivas de mutualismos.
abstract_english:
Mutualisms are interactions that increase the fitness of the individuals of different species
involved. Some mutualisms are characterized by high local species diversity and
phenotypic convergence. It has been proposed that the selective pressures imposed by
mutualisms would favor diversification and phenotypic convergence. Locally,
mutualisms form networks of interactions composed of dozens of species. The study of
how these interaction networks form and modulate selective pressures can provide
information about the processes generating high diversity and convergence in mutualisms.
We explore the role of mutualisms in diversification through models based on
individual-based models. Results indicate that stabilizing selection imposed by mutualists does not
favors diversification but rather reduces population phenotypic variance. By
Therefore, the high diversity observed in mutualisms must be associated with other
ecological and evolutionary processes. We use a combination of evolutionary models and an
analytical approach based on flow theory in complex networks to show how the
emergence of phenotypic convergence is closely associated with the way species interact in these
species interact in these networks, favoring indirect evolutionary effects. More generally, these
results suggest that the organization of mutualistic networks may be important for understanding the
understanding the evolutionary consequences of mutualisms.

title_original: Sustainable agriculture: enhancing crop yield through wild pollinators
title_english: Sustainable agriculture: enhancing crop yield through wild pollinators
abstract_original:
Recent evidence highlights the value of wild-insect species richness and abundance
for crop pollination worldwide. Yet, deliberate physical importation of single species
(eg European honey bees) into crop fields for pollination remains the mainstream
management approach, and implementation of practices to enhance crop yield
(production per area) through wild insects is only just beginning. With few

exceptions, studies measuring the impacts of pollinator-supporting practices on wild-
insect richness and pollination service success –particularly in relation to long-term

crop yield and economic profit – are rare. Here, we provide a general framework and
examples of approaches for enhancing pollinator richness and abundance, quantity
and quality of pollen on stigmas, crop yield, and farmers profit, including some
benefits detected only through long-term monitoring. We argue for integrating the
promotion of wild-insect species richness with single-species management to benefit
farmers and society.
abstract_english:
Recent evidence highlights the value of wild-insect species richness and abundance
for crop pollination worldwide. Yet, deliberate physical importation of single species
(eg European honey bees) into crop fields for pollination remains the mainstream
management approach, and implementation of practices to enhance crop yield
(production per area) through wild insects is only just beginning. With few

exceptions, studies measuring the impacts of pollinator-supporting practices on wild-
insect richness and pollination service success –particularly in relation to long-term

crop yield and economic profit – are rare. Here, we provide a general framework and
examples of approaches for enhancing pollinator richness and abundance, quantity
and quality of pollen on stigmas, crop yield, and farmers profit, including some
benefits detected only through long-term monitoring. We argue for integrating the
promotion of wild-insect species richness with single-species management to benefit
farmers and society.

title_original: Efeitos de um século de mudanças ambientais em crânios de esquilos
title_english: Effects of a century of environmental change on squirrel skulls
abstract_original: Mudanças climáticas causadas pelo homem têm alterado fundamentalmente inúmeros táxons por todo o globo. Compreender os mecanismos que levam espécies filogeneticamente próximas à respostas completamente diferentes é importante não só para entendermos o mundo natural e os respectivos papéis de diferenças ecológicas e evolutivas em um grupo, como também é extremamente relevante no desenvolvimento de modelos preditivos de como tais mudanças afetarão as espécies.    O objetivo deste trabalho foi explorar a evolução fenotípica em duas espécies de esquilos do gênero Tamias que habitam ambientes similares e são filogeneticamente próximas, porém tem respondido de maneiras opostas às mudanças ambientais. Enquanto uma espécie não sofreu mudanças em relação a sua distribuição e diversidade genética a outra mudou consideravelmente a sua distribuição além de ter reduzido sua diversidade genética. O que observamos foi um cenário similar em relação às mudanças fenotípicas: a primeira não sofreu mudanças morfológicas significativas, enquanto a outra mudou significativamente em especial nos caracteres da face. Mais que isso, testes de deriva genética mostram que estas mudanças foram ocasionadas principalmente por seleção natural direcional. Pretendo explorar nesta palestra quais os impactos e as consequências evolutivas de tais mudanças para o futuro destas espécies.
abstract_english: Human-caused climate change has fundamentally altered countless taxa across the globe. Understanding the mechanisms that lead phylogenetically close species to completely different responses is not only important for understanding the natural world and the respective roles of ecological and evolutionary differences in a group, but is also extremely relevant in developing predictive models of how such changes will affect species.    The objective of this work was to explore phenotypic evolution in two species of squirrels of the genus Tamias that inhabit similar environments and are phylogenetically close, but have responded in opposite ways to environmental changes. While one species has not changed its distribution and genetic diversity, the other has changed its distribution considerably and has reduced its genetic diversity. What we observed was a similar scenario with regard to phenotypic changes: the first did not undergo significant morphological changes, while the other changed significantly, especially in facial characters. More than that, tests of genetic drift show that these changes were mainly caused by directional natural selection. I intend to explore in this talk what the impacts and evolutionary consequences of such changes are for the future of these species.

title_original: O que sabemos sobre a mata atlântica? Revisando quase 70 anos de informações sobre a estrutura de suas florestas
title_english: What do we know about the Atlantic Rainforest? Reviewing almost 70 years of information about the structure of its forests
abstract_original:
A estrutura e composição da Mata Atlântica, um dos mais ameaçados hotspots do planeta, vêm
sendo estudada a mais de meio século. Mas, apesar das iniciativas anteriores para compilar as
informações nos trabalhos existentes, o conhecimento existente sobre as comunidades arbóreas
da Mata Atlântica encontra-se pulverizado em centenas de documentos que, em muitos casos,
são de difícil acesso. Isso dificulta uma síntese do atual conhecimento sobre esse bioma. O
objetivo deste estudo foi revisar os trabalhos quantitativos de Mata Atlântica lato sensu até o fim
de 2013 e determinar onde e como esses estudos foram realizados. Após uma revisão
sistemática realizada em diferentes bases de informação, foram encontradas referências de 1207
trabalhos publicados desde 1946 com informações sobre estrutura e/ou composição de 2462
localidades. Esses trabalhos contêm informações sobre um total de 2,51 milhões de árvores em
aproximadamente 1870 hectares. As informações disponíveis, contudo, não estiveram
uniformemente distribuídas. As florestas de tabuleiro, nebulares, caxetais e paludosas estiveram
sub-representadas. A partir dos anos 1980, o número de trabalhos publicados por ano tem
aumentado sem tendência de estabilização, sugerindo que centenas de trabalhos serão
publicados nos próximos anos. É importante, porém, que os futuros trabalhos preencham as
lacunas de conhecimento existentes.
abstract_english:
The structure and composition of the Atlantic Forest, one of the most threatened hotspots on the planet, has been
being studied for more than half a century. But despite previous initiatives to compile
information in existing studies, existing knowledge about the tree communities of the Atlantic
of the Atlantic Forest is scattered in hundreds of documents that, in many cases, are difficult to access,
difficult to access. This makes a synthesis of the current knowledge about this biome difficult. O
objective of this study was to review quantitative studies of Atlantic Forest lato sensu up to the end of 2013
2013 and determine where and how these studies were conducted. After a systematic review
review conducted in different databases, references were found to 1207 papers published since 1946
papers published since 1946 with information on structure and/or composition from 2462
sites. These papers contain information on a total of 2.51 million trees on
approximately 1870 hectares. The available information, however, was not
evenly distributed. Tableland, cloud, caixetais and paludosa forests were under-represented.
under-represented. Since the 1980s, the number of papers published per year has
increasing without a tendency to stabilize, suggesting that hundreds of papers will be published in the coming years.
published in the coming years. It is important, however, that future papers fill the
existing knowledge gaps.

title_original: Manejo de Fauna em Aeroportos e a atuação dos biólogos
title_english: Fauna Management in Airports and the role of biologists
abstract_original:
O desenvolvimento da aviação impulsionou o crescimento da preocupação com as
colisões entre animais e aeronaves (i.e. Risco da Fauna). Esses choques podem
ocasionar acidentes aéreos, perda de fauna e custos financeiros altíssimos. A
forma mais eficiente de mitigar o risco é o manejo de fauna que deve ser executado
por profissionais da área ambiental, especialistas em fauna. Os investimentos estão
crescendo e diversos aeroportos, atualmente, são obrigados a ter, no mínimo, uma
avaliação do Risco da Fauna. Esse cenário proporciona aos biólogos,
especialmente aos ecólogos, um campo de trabalho promissor que carece de
profissionais e conhecimento.
abstract_english:
The development of aviation has driven the growth of concern about
collisions between animals and aircraft (i.e. Wildlife Risk). These collisions can
lead to airplane crashes, loss of wildlife, and enormous financial costs. A
most efficient way to mitigate the risk is the fauna management that must be executed
by environmental professionals, experts in fauna. The investments are
increasing and several airports are currently obliged to have, at least, a Fauna Risk
assessment of Fauna Risk. This scenario provides biologists,
especially ecologists, a promising work field that lacks
professionals and knowledge.

title_original: Predator-Prey Arms Race and the Evolution of Tetrodotoxin Resistance in Snakes
title_english: Predator-Prey Arms Race and the Evolution of Tetrodotoxin Resistance in Snakes
abstract_original:
Tetrodotoxin (TTX) is a potent neurotoxin that acts on voltage gated sodium channels;
it is found in a wide array of organisms, including some amphibians. The presence of
TTX renders organisms generally inedible to predators. We have studied the
coevolution of the newt, Taricha granulosa and a garter snake, Thamnophis sirtalis; the
presence of TTX in the newt and the presence of resistance to TTX in the snake
seemingly have led to an escalating arms race. This arms race has resulted in
elevated TTX levels in the newt and elevated resistance levels in the snake. We have
discovered that other snakes faced with amphibian prey having TTX have adapted by
altering the sodium channels in a way similar to garter snakes. Recently we have
discovered that caddis fly larvae are resistant to TTX and feed on newt eggs. This will
require rethinking what we know” about snake-newt coevolution.”
abstract_english:
Tetrodotoxin (TTX) is a potent neurotoxin that acts on voltage gated sodium channels;
