title_original: Os bandos mistos nas Yungas da Argentina
title_english: The mixed flocks in the Yungas of Argentina
abstract_original: Os grupos de forrageamento interespecíficos de aves, os bandos mistos, são um fenómeno amplamente distribuído. As espécies que compõem os bandos mistos têm diferentes requisitos ecológicos, elas decidem formar um bando misto e forrageiam em conjunto através da floresta. Desta forma, surgem as perguntas: por que diferentes espécies de aves decidem formar bandos mistos? Estas espécies obtêm benefícios que superam os custos da formação dos bandos? Para responder a estas questões durante três anos, foram estudadas a sazonalidade dos bandos mistos, a resposta às variáveis climáticas, a resposta à disponibilidade de alimentos e, finalmente, se os participantes obtiveram benefícios nas Yungas Australes da Argentina. Nós encontramos que os bandos mistos nas Yungas do norte da Argentina têm um padrão de formação intermédio entre os bandos anuais da Amazônia e os bandos completamente sazonais das florestas temperadas. Além disso, descobrimos que os bandos mistos respondem à diminuição da temperatura a curto prazo e que se formam quando o alimento é mais difícil de encontrar. Finalmente, descobrimos que as aves que formam bandos mistos têm uma maior eficiência de forrageamento em comparação com a forragem isolada. Ainda há muitas perguntas a serem respondidas, e mais pesquisa é a maneira de respondê-las.
abstract_english: The interspecific foraging groups of birds, mixed flocks, are a widely distributed phenomenon. The species that make up mixed flocks have different ecological requirements, they decide to form a mixed flock and forage together through the forest. Thus, the questions arise: why do different species of birds decide to form mixed flocks? Do these species obtain benefits that outweigh the costs of forming flocks? To answer these questions over three years, we studied the seasonality of mixed flocks, the response to climatic variables, the response to food availability, and finally whether participants obtained benefits in the Yungas Australes of Argentina. We found that mixed flocks in the Yungas of northern Argentina have an intermediate formation pattern between the annual flocks of the Amazon and the completely seasonal flocks of temperate forests. In addition, we found that mixed flocks respond to decreasing temperature in the short term and that they form when food is harder to find. Finally, we found that birds that form mixed flocks have higher foraging efficiency compared to foraging alone. There are still many questions to be answered, and more research is the way to answer them.
institute: Instituto de Bio y Geociencias de NOA

title_original: Serpentes constritoras como conectoras em redes de interação predador-presa
title_english: Constrictor snakes as connectors in predator-prey interaction networks
abstract_original:
Em comunidades, interações entre espécies formam redes, sendo o tipo mais fundamental de
rede ecológica aquela que descreve conexões alimentares entre organismos. Um problema
fundamental é tentar entender como os processos ecológicos e evolutivos que atuam
primariamente nos indivíduos e populações estruturam redes tróficas entre espécies de
consumidores e seus recursos. Uma importante característica dos indivíduos que influencia sua
capacidade de consumir recursos e tem consequência para a organização de redes ecológicas é o
tamanho do corpo dos predadores. Supondo que quanto maior o predador, maior a amplitude de
recursos alimentares consumidos, essa relação deve levar a emergência de um padrão
aninhado em redes ecológicas. Consequentemente, espera-se que desvios do padrão
perfeitamente aninhado sejam gerados pelo consumo de recursos que requerem adaptações
específicas. Neste sentido, espera-se que que a existência de diferentes grupos de consumidores
especializados em recursos particulares leve a formação, na escala da rede, de um padrão
modular de interações. Neste trabalho investigamos essas previsões por meio da caracterização
trófica de uma comunidade rica e bem estudada de serpentes amazônicas. Especificamente, nós
integramos análises da estrutura de redes com simulações de remoção de espécies para avaliar
o papel das diferentes espécies de serpentes na estruturação dessa comunidade.
abstract_english:
In communities, interactions between species form networks, the most fundamental type of
ecological network is that which describes food connections between organisms. A fundamental
fundamental problem is to try to understand how ecological and evolutionary processes that act
individuals and populations structure trophic networks between consumer species and their resources.
consumers and their resources. An important characteristic of individuals that influences their
ability to consume resources and has consequences for the organization of ecological networks is the body size of predators.
size of predators. Assuming that the larger the predator, the greater the range of
food resources consumed, this relationship should lead to the emergence of a nested
nested pattern in ecological networks. Consequently, deviations from the
perfectly nested pattern are expected to be generated by the consumption of resources that require specific adaptations.
specific adaptations. In this sense, it is expected that the existence of different groups of consumers
specialized in particular resources is expected to lead to the formation, at the network scale, of a modular pattern of interactions.
modular pattern of interactions. In this work we investigate these predictions by means of trophic
trophic characterization of a rich and well-studied community of Amazonian snakes. Specifically, we
integrate network structure analyses with species removal simulations to assess
the role of different snake species in structuring this community.

title_original: Porque o cachorro do mato atravessou a estrada? Características da paisagem associadas à mortalidade por atropelamento de Cerdocyon thous
title_english: Why did the bush dog cross the road? Landscape features associated with trampling mortality of Cerdocyon thous
abstract_original:
A mortalidade de animais silvestres em estradas é uma das principais causas de perda de
indivíduos de espécies nativas por ação antrópica. Estima-se que pelo menos 14 milhões de
vertebrados morram atropelados por ano só no Brasil. Grande parte destes números são
mamíferos nativos, que ao se movimentarem pela paisagem acabam encontrando as rodovias e
podem ser atropelados.
Uma das espécies mais frequentemente afetadas é o Cerdocyon thous, popularmente conhecido
como cachorro-do-mato, é uma espécie bastante generalista que ocorre em quase todo o
território brasileiro. Através da análise de pontos de atropelamentos em todo o Brasil é possível
entender quais as características da paisagem estão associadas à mortalidade do animal em
rodovias brasileiras, e com isso é possível entender além da ocorrência, as áreas de maior risco
para a espécie próximo às rodovias, além de pensar em medidas de mitigação e de impacto da
malha viária sobre esse e demais mamíferos nativos brasileiros.
abstract_english:
The mortality of wild animals on roads is one of the main causes of loss of native
individuals of native species by anthropic action. It is estimated that at least 14 million
vertebrates die run over by cars each year in Brazil alone. A large part of these numbers are native
native mammals, that when moving through the landscape end up finding the highways and can be run over by cars.
can be run over.
One of the most frequently affected species is the Cerdocyon thous, popularly known as the bush dog.
It is a very generalist species that occurs in almost the entire Brazilian territory.
the Brazilian territory. Through the analysis of road kills throughout Brazil it is possible to understand which landscape
which landscape features are associated with the mortality of the animal on Brazilian roads, and
Brazilian roads, and with this it is possible to understand, besides the occurrence, the areas of greatest risk
to the species near the highways, in addition to thinking about mitigation measures and the impact of the
road network on this and other native Brazilian mammals.

title_original: Bioquímica da ressaca
title_english: Biochemistry of hangover
abstract_original:
Não há dúvidas de que a ingestão de bebidas alcoólicas está acompanhada, na maioria dos
casos, pela busca pelo prazer ou pelo alívio. As bebidas alcoólicas estão presentes em muitos
eventos sociais e, desde muitos séculos, tem sido consumidas em escala crescente pela
humanidade. Contudo, é muito comum entre os apreciadores de bebidas alcoólicas a
preocupação sobre como será o dia seguinte”. O que exatamente ocorre com o nosso corpo
quando ingerimos bebidas que contém álcool? A ingestão de álcool é mesmo prejudicial? A
ressaca é inevitável? Nesta apresentação dedicada ao EcoEncontros irei discutir esses e outros
aspectos da fisiologia da ingestão de álcool e do que ocorre durante a ressaca. Espero que as
informações que irei trazer a todos os presentes possam auxiliar no entendimento de como se dá
nossa relação com o consumo de bebidas alcóolicas e quais as consequências!”
abstract_english:
There is no doubt that the ingestion of alcoholic beverages is accompanied, in most cases, by the search for pleasure or relief.
cases, by the search for pleasure or relief. Alcoholic beverages are present at many
social events and, for many centuries, have been consumed on an increasing scale by mankind.
mankind. However, it is very common among lovers of alcoholic beverages to
worry about what the next day will be like. What exactly happens to our bodies
when we ingest beverages containing alcohol? Is drinking alcohol really harmful? A
hangover inevitable? In this presentation dedicated to EcoEncontros, I will discuss these and other
aspects of the physiology of alcohol intake and what happens during a hangover. I hope that the
I hope that the information I will bring to all of you can help you understand how we relate to
our relationship with the consumption of alcoholic beverages and what the consequences are!"

title_original: Species, speciation, and the origins of biological diversity
title_english: Species, speciation, and the origins of biological diversity
abstract_original: Speciation – the process by which new species originate - is a fundamental process in evolutionary biology. Under the biological species concept, a species is a set of populations that are united by gene flow and which maintain independence from other such populations through the property of reproductive isolation. For this reason, the study of speciation has largely been equated with the study of genetic barriers to gene exchange between populations. Here, I describe an expanded framework for conceptualizing speciation that emphasizes key roles for processes other than reproductive isolation in the origins of biological diversity. These additional factors include those that affect the origin and persistence of demographically-isolated populations. I develop a general test for quantifying the contribution of these and other processes to the speciation process more generally, and I apply the framework to a number of vertebrate clades. I describe limits to our understanding of evolution that follow from a near-exclusive focus on reproductive isolation in speciation biology.
abstract_english: Speciation – the process by which new species originate - is a fundamental process in evolutionary biology. Under the biological species concept, a species is a set of populations that are united by gene flow and which maintain independence from other such populations through the property of reproductive isolation. For this reason, the study of speciation has largely been equated with the study of genetic barriers to gene exchange between populations. Here, I describe an expanded framework for conceptualizing speciation that emphasizes key roles for processes other than reproductive isolation in the origins of biological diversity. These additional factors include those that affect the origin and persistence of demographically-isolated populations. I develop a general test for quantifying the contribution of these and other processes to the speciation process more generally, and I apply the framework to a number of vertebrate clades. I describe limits to our understanding of evolution that follow from a near-exclusive focus on reproductive isolation in speciation biology.

title_original: Estoque de carbono de florestas tropicais secundárias em paisagens antropizadas
title_english: Carbon stocks of secondary tropical forests in anthropized landscapes
abstract_original: As florestas tropicais têm sofrido intensa transformação ao longo dos últimos anos e mais da metade das florestas tropicais e subtropicais já se encontra totalmente convertida em áreas agrícolas e urbanas. Das florestas remanescentes, cerca de 60% são florestas secundárias, que já sofreram algum tipo de perturbação antrópica. O estoque de carbono nestas florestas pode variar muito e essa variação pode ocorrer em diferentes escalas espaciais. Nessa palestra, apresento o trabalho que desenvolvi durante meu doutorado, onde explorei como essas variações no nível da paisagem e local modulam o estoque de carbono, considerando em particular seus efeitos em florestas maduras (em processo de fragmentação) e em florestas jovens. Foram usadas como sistema de estudo, florestas secundárias da Mata Atlântica em duas regiões com condições contrastantes de paisagem: no sistema Cantareira (SP), onde a floresta foi intensamente perturbada e fragmentada, e no Parque da Serra do Conduru (BA), onde a cobertura florestal ainda predomina.
abstract_english: Tropical forests have been undergoing intense transformation over the last few years, and more than half of the tropical and subtropical forests are already fully converted into agricultural and urban areas. Of the remaining forests, about 60% are secondary forests, which have already suffered some kind of anthropogenic disturbance. The carbon stock in these forests can vary greatly and this variation can occur at different spatial scales. In this talk, I present the work that I developed during my PhD, where I explored how these variations at the landscape and local level modulate carbon stocks, considering in particular their effects in mature forests (undergoing fragmentation) and young forests. As a study system, secondary forests of the Atlantic Forest in two regions with contrasting landscape conditions were used: in the Cantareira system (SP), where the forest has been intensely disturbed and fragmented, and in the Serra do Conduru Park (BA), where forest cover still predominates.

title_original: Informing conservation by linking animal use of space to demography
title_english: Informing conservation by linking animal use of space to demography
abstract_original:
Excursions by wildlife out of protected areas and into landscapes impacted by human activity are a
widespread challenge in contemporary conservation. Interventions to mitigate the resulting
human-wildlife conflicts are often expensive and do not necessarily account for fine-scale patterns of
animal movement. In this presentation, I will illustrate two broadly applicable methods that can be
used to relate animal use of space to population dynamics through the example of bison (Bison bison)
in Prince Albert National Park (PANP), Canada, which regularly leave the protected area to venture
into agricultural fields where they are exposed to unsustainable hunting. The first is based on a Cox
proportional hazards model which relates a spatial pattern of interest to a vital rate such as, in our
case, survival of adult females. This relationship is added to a classic Lefkovitch matrix population
model to project population abundance as a function of the spatial pattern. The second method relies
on building an empirical model of animal movement which is used to parametrize an individual-based
model (IBM) simulating animal movement and mortality. Overall, both methods can inform
management by leading to complementary insights on where best to intervene and on how animals
should react to such interventions.
abstract_english:
Excursions by wildlife out of protected areas and into landscapes impacted by human activity are a
widespread challenge in contemporary conservation. Interventions to mitigate the resulting
human-wildlife conflicts are often expensive and do not necessarily account for fine-scale patterns of
animal movement. In this presentation, I will illustrate two broadly applicable methods that can be
used to relate animal use of space to population dynamics through the example of bison (Bison bison)
in Prince Albert National Park (PANP), Canada, which regularly leave the protected area to venture
into agricultural fields where they are exposed to unsustainable hunting. The first is based on a Cox
proportional hazards model which relates a spatial pattern of interest to a vital rate such as, in our
case, survival of adult females. This relationship is added to a classic Lefkovitch matrix population
model to project population abundance as a function of the spatial pattern. The second method relies
on building an empirical model of animal movement which is used to parametrize an individual-based
model (IBM) simulating animal movement and mortality. Overall, both methods can inform
management by leading to complementary insights on where best to intervene and on how animals
should react to such interventions.

title_original: Amphibians in a changing world: challenges and opportunities
title_english: Amphibians in a changing world: challenges and opportunities
abstract_original: The biodiversity of the Earth is in crisis. The global change drivers responsible for that are several, including climate change, biological invasions and land use change. Amphibians are the main symbol of this crisis, with almost 40% of its species with important conservation problems. In addition to those mentioned drivers, amphibians are threatened by a deadly (chytrid) fungus that has caused several world population declines and species extinctions. In this talk, I will show you the impact of climate change, land use and the chytrid fungus might have on all amphibian species of the chilean biodiversity hotspot and what conservation actions we might take to tackle this huge environmental problem.
abstract_english: The biodiversity of the Earth is in crisis. The global change drivers responsible for that are several, including climate change, biological invasions and land use change. Amphibians are the main symbol of this crisis, with almost 40% of its species with important conservation problems. In addition to those mentioned drivers, amphibians are threatened by a deadly (chytrid) fungus that has caused several world population declines and species extinctions. In this talk, I will show you the impact of climate change, land use and the chytrid fungus might have on all amphibian species of the chilean biodiversity hotspot and what conservation actions we might take to tackle this huge environmental problem.

title_original: Development and applications of mechanistic models of animal use of space in heterogeneous and dynamic environments
title_english: Development and applications of mechanistic models of animal use of space in heterogeneous and dynamic environments
abstract_original: Increases in natural and anthropogenic disturbances in native environments create an urgent need for robust and effective modelling tools capable of forecasting changes in the use of space of animals ranging in dynamic landscapes. Here I will present novel mathematical and statistical models that can be used to understand and simulate the spatial distribution of animals in dynamic landscapes. Specifically, I will 1) show how to account for correlation in movement datasets when assessing habitat selection, 2) present a statistical model of animal movement that simultaneously identifies behavioral phases (e.g., foraging, resting, migrating) and the habitat selection attributes specific to each phase, 3) present a mathematical model integrating the spatiotemporal dynamics of animal movement within a network of resource patches, and 4) show how this model can be used to anticipate changes in animal distribution following landscape fragmentation from anthropogenic sources and the differential impact of disturbances in different locations of the network. Overall, this presentation will showcase several useful tools that are broadly applicable to more precisely and realistically understand and model animal movement in different ecological contexts.
abstract_english: Increases in natural and anthropogenic disturbances in native environments create an urgent need for robust and effective modelling tools capable of forecasting changes in the use of space of animals ranging in dynamic landscapes. Here I will present novel mathematical and statistical models that can be used to understand and simulate the spatial distribution of animals in dynamic landscapes. Specifically, I will 1) show how to account for correlation in movement datasets when assessing habitat selection, 2) present a statistical model of animal movement that simultaneously identifies behavioral phases (e.g., foraging, resting, migrating) and the habitat selection attributes specific to each phase, 3) present a mathematical model integrating the spatiotemporal dynamics of animal movement within a network of resource patches, and 4) show how this model can be used to anticipate changes in animal distribution following landscape fragmentation from anthropogenic sources and the differential impact of disturbances in different locations of the network. Overall, this presentation will showcase several useful tools that are broadly applicable to more precisely and realistically understand and model animal movement in different ecological contexts.

title_original: Biogeografia e evolução da concha em caramujos marinhos
title_english: Biogeography and evolution of the shell in marine snails
abstract_original: Gastrópodes são os invertebrados com maior número de espécies nos oceanos modernos. Nesse EcoEncontros, apresentarei dois projetos sobre a evolução de caramujos marinhos em escala geológica. É considerado que a intensificação de predação agiu como uma força seletiva para a evolução de conchas mais bens defendidas. Para testar a hipótese, estudei o morfoespaço da forma de centenas de conchas fósseis, mostrando que conchas espirais mais baixas e lapas achatadas se tornaram mais diversas com o tempo. Esse padrão parece ser derivado da evolução independente da forma da concha em diferentes famílias de vetigastrópodes. Apresentarei em seguida uma filogenia molecular calibrada da família Fissurellidae, estimando a origem do grupo no Indo-Pacífico oeste há cerca de 175 milhões de anos, colonizando novos oceanos via o corredor marinho de Tethys conforme o supercontinente Pangea se separou.
abstract_english: Gastropods are the most species-rich invertebrates in modern oceans. In this EcoEncontros, I will present two projects on the evolution of marine snails on a geological scale. It is hypothesized that the intensification of predation acted as a selective force for the evolution of more well-defended shells. To test the hypothesis, I studied the shape morphospace of hundreds of fossil shells, showing that lower spiral shells and flattened limpets became more diverse over time. This pattern seems to be derived from independent evolution of shell shape in different families of vetigastropods. I will then present a calibrated molecular phylogeny of the family Fissurellidae, estimating the origin of the group in the western Indo-Pacific about 175 million years ago, colonizing new oceans via the Tethys marine corridor as the supercontinent Pangea broke up.

title_original: Persistência de mutualismos com exploradores
title_english: Persistence of mutualisms with exploiters
abstract_original: Os mutualismos são interações mutuamente benéficas, geralmente compostas por grandes redes de espécies que formam a base da maioria das comunidades ecológicas. As comunidades mutualistas também possuem espécies que não oferecem benefícios, conhecidas como exploradores. Possíveis fatores que podem levar à coexistência entre exploradores e mutualistas não estão claros. Utilizando um sistema de leveduras, exploro dois mecanismos possíveis que podem levar à persistência de mutualismos sob exploração. Primeiro, mostro que a alta riqueza de espécies das comunidades mutualistas torna as comunidades mais resistentes ao colapso por exploração, corroborando o papel da riqueza de espécies em fornecer redundância funcional a comunidade mutualistas. Segundo, mostro que a coevolução entre parceiros mutualistas pode levar à resistência contra invasões por exploradores, independentemente da obrigatoriedade da interação mutualística. Esses resultados nos informam sobre meios que podem levar a persistência de mutualismos que observamos na natureza, sem a necessidade de mecanismos de controle dos parceiros.
abstract_english: Mutualisms are mutually beneficial interactions, usually composed of large networks of species that form the basis of most ecological communities. Mutualistic communities also have non-beneficial species, known as exploiters. Possible factors that may lead to coexistence between exploiters and mutualists are unclear. Using a yeast system, I explore two possible mechanisms that may lead to the persistence of mutualisms under exploitation. First, I show that high species richness of mutualistic communities makes communities more resistant to collapse by exploitation, corroborating the role of species richness in providing functional redundancy to mutualistic communities. Second, I show that coevolution among mutualistic partners can lead to resistance against invasion by exploiters, regardless of whether the mutualistic interaction is compulsory. These results inform us about means that can lead to the persistence of mutualisms that we observe in nature, without the need for partner control mechanisms.

title_original: Esse crush vale um jantar caro? O caso de uma aranha com presente nupcial
title_english: Is that crush worth an expensive dinner? The case of a spider with a bridal gift
abstract_original:
Durante a escolha de parceiras, os machos geralmente têm comportamentos promíscuos e copulam com todas as fêmeas possíveis. Este padrão se deve ao fato de o sucesso reprodutivo dos machos estar relacionado à quantidade de parceiras, e pouco com a qualidade delas. No entanto existem machos que investem mais recursos em reprodução, tornando-a custosa e, portanto, limitando a reprodução indiscriminada. Nesses casos, espera-se que os machos sejam seletivos durante a escolha de parceiras reprodutivas.
 Durante meu mestrado trabalharei com uma espécie de aranha brasileira cujos machos oferecem para a fêmea uma presa envolta em seda como presente durante a cópula. Como oferecer presa para a fêmea tem como consequência deixar de comer, será que o macho ajusta a qualidade do presente e sua performance reprodutiva segundo características da fêmea?
abstract_english:
During mate selection, males usually engage in promiscuous behavior and copulate with as many females as possible. This pattern is due to the fact that the reproductive success of males is related to the quantity of mates, and little to their quality. However, there are males that invest more resources in reproduction, making it costly and therefore limiting indiscriminate reproduction. In these cases the males are expected to be selective during the choice of reproductive partners.
 During my master's degree I will work with a Brazilian spider species whose males offer the female a silk wrapped prey as a gift during copulation. Since offering prey to the female has as a consequence to stop eating, does the male adjust the quality of the gift and his reproductive performance according to female characteristics?

title_original: Anatomical multifunctionality and the diversification of skull morphology in bats
title_english: Anatomical multifunctionality and the diversification of skull morphology in bats
abstract_original: The vertebrate skull performs multiple functions, including feeding, protecting the brain and supporting the sensory organs. Dietary demands are considered a major evolutionary driver of skull diversity in mammals, but there have been few, large-scale, quantitative studies that have tested the impact of various functions on skull morphological diversification. Bats are an ideal system to investigate this topic because they are highly diverse in species richness, skull morphology, diet, and sensory modalities. In this talk, I will present our recent findings on how sensory and dietary functions may have shaped the evolution of skull diversity across the bat radiation, along with insights from modeling work that examines the potential performance implications of skull features that are unique to bats.
abstract_english: The vertebrate skull performs multiple functions, including feeding, protecting the brain and supporting the sensory organs. Dietary demands are considered a major evolutionary driver of skull diversity in mammals, but there have been few, large-scale, quantitative studies that have tested the impact of various functions on skull morphological diversification. Bats are an ideal system to investigate this topic because they are highly diverse in species richness, skull morphology, diet, and sensory modalities. In this talk, I will present our recent findings on how sensory and dietary functions may have shaped the evolution of skull diversity across the bat radiation, along with insights from modeling work that examines the potential performance implications of skull features that are unique to bats.

title_original: A probabilidade de extinção muda com a idade da espécie?
title_english: Does the probability of extinction change with the age of the species?
abstract_original: Sabemos que grande parte dos indivíduos passam pelo processo de senescência, que resulta em maior probabilidade de mortalidade ao longo do avanço da idade. Mas e quanto aos outros níveis de organização biológica? A probabilidade de extinção pode estar associada à idade das espécies, já que os processos evolutivos pelos quais elas passam podem torná-las mais resistentes a um novo ambiente ou criar restrições à sua evolução. Existe também um terceiro cenário, tradicionalmente relacionado à hipótese da rainha vermelha, em que a probabilidade de extinção seria independente da idade da espécie. Apesar da ligação entre idade e extinção já ter sido investigada, a maioria das análises feitas até então não incorporou uma série de vieses importantes que sabemos que o registro fóssil possui. Em nosso trabalho, usamos ocorrências fósseis e modelos probabilísticos, que explicitamente levam esses vieses em consideração, para avaliar se a distribuição da duração das espécies e gêneros de ruminantes indicam uma ligação entre idade e probabilidade de extinção no nível das espécies e dos gêneros. Nossas estimativas indicam que a probabilidade de extinção decresce com a idade das espécies, e que a extinção dos gêneros é apenas parcialmente explicada pela extinção das espécies. Assim, sugerimos que os padrões macroevolutivos de sobrevivência das linhagens mudam em diferentes escalas da árvore da vida.
abstract_english: We know that a large portion of individuals go through the process of senescence, which results in a greater likelihood of mortality as age advances. But what about the other levels of biological organization? The probability of extinction may be associated with the age of the species, since the evolutionary processes they go through may make them more resistant to a new environment or create constraints on their evolution. There is also a third scenario, traditionally related to the red queen hypothesis, in which the probability of extinction would be independent of the age of the species. Although the link between age and extinction has already been investigated, most analyses done so far have not incorporated a number of important biases that we know the fossil record possesses. In our work, we use fossil occurrences and probabilistic models, which explicitly take these biases into account, to assess whether the distribution of the duration of ruminant species and genera indicate a link between age and extinction probability at the species and genus level. Our estimates indicate that extinction probability decreases with species age, and that extinction of genera is only partially explained by species extinction. Thus, we suggest that macroevolutionary patterns of lineage survival change at different scales of the tree of life.

title_original: Implicações das  interações sociais na termorregulação e uso do habitat na conquista de novos ambientes
title_english: Implications of social interactions for thermoregulation and habitat use in the conquest of new environments
abstract_original: A aptidão em lagartos está estreitamente atrelada à possibilidade de seleção de microambientes com temperaturas que permitam a realização dos processos fisiológicos. A manutenção das temperaturas corporais próximas às temperaturas ótimas somente é possível quando os organismos conseguem superar problemas diversos, tais como a diminuição da disponibilidade de microambientes termais adequados ou a presença de outros indivíduos que compartilham o mesmo habitat. Nesta oportunidade exploraremos as possíveis influências das interações sociais entre três espécies de lagartos em seus respectivos comportamentos termorregulatórios e o uso de habitat. Depois de serem introduzidos nas ilhas havaianas, Anolis sagrei, A. carolinensis e Phelsuma laticauda co-ocorrem em diversos ambientes onde competem por recursos alimentares e térmicos. A utilização de recintos seminaturais, observações diárias e imagens termográficas permitiram registrar a variação individual do comportamento exploratório e termorregulatório frente a diferentes scenarios. Espera-se que os resultados contribuam no entendimento de como eventuais mudanças no uso de microambientes térmicos podem influenciar a distribuição das espécies através das ilhas.
abstract_english: Fitness in lizards is closely linked to the possibility of selecting microenvironments with temperatures that allow physiological processes to take place. The maintenance of body temperatures close to the optimal temperatures is only possible when the organisms can overcome various problems, such as the decreased availability of suitable thermal microenvironments or the presence of other individuals sharing the same habitat. In this opportunity we will explore the possible influences of social interactions between three lizard species on their respective thermoregulatory behaviors and habitat use. After being introduced to the Hawaiian Islands, Anolis sagrei, A. carolinensis, and Phelsuma laticauda co-occur in diverse environments where they compete for food and thermal resources. The use of semi-natural enclosures, daily observations and thermographic images allowed recording the individual variation in exploratory and thermoregulatory behavior in the face of different scenarios. The results are expected to contribute to the understanding of how changes in the use of thermal microenvironments may influence the distribution of species across islands.

title_original: Febril ou apático? respostas comportamentais de anuros quando estão infectados por estímulos pró-inflamatórios
title_english: Feverish or apathetic? Behavioral responses of anurans when they are infected by pro-inflammatory stimuli
abstract_original:
As infecções ou patógenos podem produzir mudanças nos mecanismos usados para a
termorregulação nos animais. Nos tetrápodes ectotérmicos, como anuros, indivíduos
infectados têm apresentado temperaturas corporais altas, considerando-se como Febre
comportamental. No entanto existem outros comportamentos que poderiam ser alternos a
febre comportamental, como comportamento de apatia (ou doente) que é uma resposta bem
conhecida em outras linhagens, como por exemplo, mamíferos. A palestra visa apresentar
esses dois mecanismos: febre comportamental e comportamento de apatia como possíveis
respostas em anuros e mostrar uma proposta de estudo tanto no laboratório como em
semicativeiro para conhecer se existe dominância por alguma destas respostas de defesa em
anuros.
abstract_english:
Infections or pathogens can produce changes in the mechanisms used for
thermoregulation in animals. In ectothermic tetrapods, such as anurans, infected individuals
infected individuals have exhibited high body temperatures, considered as behavioral
behavioral. However, there are other behaviors that could be alternates to
behavioral fever, such as apathetic (or sick) behavior, which is a well-known response in other
known in other lineages, such as mammals. The lecture aims to present
these two mechanisms: behavioral fever and apathetic behavior as possible responses in
responses in anurans and show a proposal for a study both in the laboratory and in
to know if there is dominance for any of these defense responses in anurans.
anurans.

title_original: Por ser de lá do sertão: soltura experimental da arara-azul-de-lear na população funcionalmente extinta do Boqueirão da Onça.
title_english: Being from the sertão: experimental release of the hyacinth macaw in the functionally extinct population of Boqueirão da Onça.
abstract_original: A arara-azul-de-lear (Anodorhynchus leari) é uma espécie endêmica da Caatinga do Norte da Bahia e listada como ameaçada de extinção. Com um total de aproximadamente 1.500 indivíduos a espécie se distribui em 2 localidades. A totalidade se concentra na ecorregião do Raso da Catarina e, a quase 200km de distância, 2 indivíduos sobrevivem no Boqueirão da Onça. Seguindo as recomendações do PAN das aves da Caatinga, um projeto de soltura experimental busca o revigoramento da população funcionalmente extinta no Boqueirão. A primeira soltura de indivíduos aconteceu em janeiro/2019 e os primeiros dados de uso do habitat serão apresentados.
abstract_english: The Hyacinth Macaw (Anodorhynchus leari) is an endemic species of the Caatinga of northern Bahia and is listed as endangered. With a total of approximately 1,500 individuals, the species is distributed in 2 localities. The totality is concentrated in the Raso da Catarina ecoregion and, almost 200 km away, 2 individuals survive in Boqueirão da Onça. Following the recommendations of the PAN for birds of the Caatinga, an experimental release project seeks to reinvigorate the functionally extinct population in the Boqueirão. The first release of individuals took place in January/2019 and the first data on habitat use will be presented.

title_original: Como se inscrever em programas de PhD, postdoc e empregos nos EUA
title_english: How to apply for PhD programs, postdocs and jobs in the USA
abstract_original: O título é auto-explicativo (!), mas nesta palestra eu darei dicas sobre o processo de inscrição para cursar doutorado nos EUA e se inscrever em postdocs e empregos. Abordarei temas como cartas de recomendação, GRE, teaching, diversity e research statement, e como escrever uma cover letter. Também falarei brevemente sobre o processo que envolve tenure nos EUA e sobre a cultura acadêmica das instituições que conheço. Devido aos recentes cortes no investimento em ciência e educação no Brasil, espero que ao final da palestra você sinta que possui informações necessárias caso queira perseguir uma carreira fora do Brasil, especificamente nos EUA.
abstract_english: The title is self-explanatory (!), but in this talk I will give you tips on the application process for pursuing a PhD in the US and applying for postdocs and jobs. I will cover topics such as letters of recommendation, GRE, teaching, diversity and research statement, and how to write a cover letter. I will also briefly discuss the process involved in tenure in the USA and the academic culture of the institutions I know. Due to recent cuts in investment in science and education in Brazil, I hope that by the end of the lecture you will feel that you have the information you need if you want to pursue a career outside of Brazil, specifically in the US.

title_original: Sensoriamento remoto em ecologia animal: insights’ em como utilizar repositórios de dados livres
title_english: Remote sensing in animal ecology: insights on how to use free data repositories
abstract_original: O acesso facilitado a grandes bases de dados de imagens de satélite possibilita novas formas de relacionar séries temporais de clima, vegetação e demografia de fauna silvestre. Nesse EcoEncontro, pretendo falar sobre o uso destes dados espaciais para melhor entender o papel do clima e de processos ecossistêmicos na dinâmica de populações e comunidades animais. Usarei exemplos de meus estudos em andamento que vão desde ungulados e tartarugas de ambientes mediterrâneos até aves em regiões Neotropicais.
abstract_english: The easy access to large databases of satellite images enables new ways to relate time series of climate, vegetation and wildlife demography. In this EcoEncontro, I intend to talk about the use of these spatial data to better understand the role of climate and ecosystem processes in the dynamics of animal populations and communities. I will use examples from my ongoing studies ranging from ungulates and turtles in Mediterranean environments to birds in Neotropical regions.

title_original: Plantações mistas como estratégia de restauração
title_english: Mixed croplands as a restoration strategy
abstract_original:
Nino apresentará um panorama da sua pesquisa de doutorado, realizado na USP/ESALQ sobre plantações mistas de alta diversidade que intercalam eucalipto e espécies de árvores da Mata Atlântica. Essa alternativa silvicultural foi pensada e testada, na BA e ES, como um sistema temporário para a restauração de reservas legais. Venha conhecer um pouco desse 
trabalho e entender como essas florestas funcionam.
abstract_english:
Nino will present an overview of his doctoral research, conducted at USP/ESALQ on high diversity mixed plantations that intersperse eucalyptus and Atlantic Forest tree species. This silvicultural alternative was thought and tested, in BA and ES, as a temporary system for the restoration of legal reserves. Come learn a little about this 
work and understand how these forests work.

title_original: Deciphering the secret lives of whales: reconstruction of decade-long patterns in reproduction and stress via baleen hormones
title_english: Deciphering the secret lives of whales: reconstruction of decade-long patterns in reproduction and stress via baleen hormones
abstract_original: Understanding patterns of stress and reproduction in wildlife is essential for effective conservation and management. In large whales, however, blood sampling for endocrine analyses is impossible, and the animals are extremely difficult to observe and may disappear to unknown areas for large parts of the year. Essential parameters such as inter-calving intervals and gestation length are still only roughly estimated, location of the breeding grounds is still unknown for many species, and the potential stressful effects of human interactions are often poorly understood. In this talk, Dr. Hunt will focus on her whale research, describing endocrine analyses that employ whale feces, respiratory vapor (blow), and baleen. Baleen is currently providing unprecedented insight into calving frequency, gestation length, testosterone cycling in males, month and location of breeding, and the physiological stress associated with fishing gear entanglement and disease epidemics. Dr. Hunt will describe her latest results from bowhead whales, southern right whales, and humpbacks, including new data to be presented soon at two international meetings.
abstract_english: Understanding patterns of stress and reproduction in wildlife is essential for effective conservation and management. In large whales, however, blood sampling for endocrine analyses is impossible, and the animals are extremely difficult to observe and may disappear to unknown areas for large parts of the year. Essential parameters such as inter-calving intervals and gestation length are still only roughly estimated, location of the breeding grounds is still unknown for many species, and the potential stressful effects of human interactions are often poorly understood. In this talk, Dr. Hunt will focus on her whale research, describing endocrine analyses that employ whale feces, respiratory vapor (blow), and baleen. Baleen is currently providing unprecedented insight into calving frequency, gestation length, testosterone cycling in males, month and location of breeding, and the physiological stress associated with fishing gear entanglement and disease epidemics. Dr. Hunt will describe her latest results from bowhead whales, southern right whales, and humpbacks, including new data to be presented soon at two international meetings.

title_original: Efeitos da matriz em comunidades de aves em paisagens fragmentadas
title_english: Matrix effects on bird communities in fragmented landscapes
abstract_original: Como as matrizes agrícolas influenciam as comunidades florestais? Qual a contribuição relativa de processos ecológicos na (des)montagem de comunidades após a perda de habitat em paisagens fragmentadas? Neste estudo investigamos como processos neutros (limitação à dispersão e deriva) e de filtro ambiental variam entre comunidades de aves em paisagens com matrizes de alta e baixa qualidade. Avaliamos estes processos para aves especialistas e generalistas, nas escalas local e da paisagem. Nossos resultados ressaltam a importância de se entender os processos que atuam sobre as comunidades para mitigar os efeitos negativos de distúrbios humanos.”
abstract_english: How do agricultural matrices influence forest communities? What is the relative contribution of ecological processes in the (dis)assembly of communities after habitat loss in fragmented landscapes? In this study we investigate how neutral (limiting dispersal and drift) and environmental filter processes vary between bird communities in landscapes with high and low quality matrices. We assessed these processes for specialist and generalist birds at local and landscape scales. Our results underscore the importance of understanding the processes acting on communities to mitigate the negative effects of human disturbance."

title_original: Seleção de habitat de aves migratórias e residentes em ambientes urbanos
title_english: Habitat selection of migratory and resident birds in urban environments
abstract_original: As paisagens urbanas favorecem os estudos de seleção de hábitat devido aos diferentes tipos de ambientes que costumam apresentar. Quando um animal usa ambientes desproporcionalmente à sua disponibilidade, a seleção de habitat é considerada, sendo expressa por preferências positivas ou negativas para diferentes tipos de habitat. Os estudos de seleção de hábitats foram realizados principalmente no Hemisfério Norte e menos na América do Sul, o continente com maior biodiversidade. Nessa palestra apresentarei meu estudo de Iniciação Científica que tem como objetivo investigar padrões de uso de habitat de quatro espécies de aves migratórias e duas espécies residentes da família Tyrannidae (Passeriformes) em paisagens urbanas, utilizando a técnica do spot-mapping.
abstract_english: Urban landscapes favor habitat selection studies because of the different types of environments they usually present. When an animal uses environments disproportionately to their availability, habitat selection is considered and is expressed by positive or negative preferences for different habitat types. Habitat selection studies have been conducted mainly in the Northern Hemisphere and less in South America, the continent with the greatest biodiversity. In this talk I will present my Scientific Initiation study that aims to investigate habitat use patterns of four migratory bird species and two resident species of the family Tyrannidae (Passeriformes) in urban landscapes using the spot-mapping technique.

title_original: Novos padrões globais de vulnerabilidade climática em animais do ceu, do mar e da terra
title_english: New global patterns of climate vulnerability in animals of the sky, sea and land
abstract_original:
Conforme a temperatura global aumenta, espera-se que
aumente também a altitude dos pisos climáticos de
montanhas. Por esse motivo, populações e/ou espécies que
não consigam tolerar as novas condições climáticas e
potenciais novos competidores vindos de regiões baixas
podem estar condenados à extirpação do topo das montanhas.
Nesta palestra, apresentarei resultados de minhas pesquisas
sobre a vulnerabilidade climática, competição e distribuição de
lagartos montanheses, dentro e fora dos trópicos.
abstract_english:
As global temperatures increase, it is expected that
the altitude of mountain climate floors is expected to increase.
mountains. For this reason, populations and/or species that
can't tolerate the new climatic conditions and potential new
potential new competitors from lower regions may be doomed
may be doomed to extirpation from the mountain tops.
In this talk, I will present results from my research
on the climatic vulnerability, competition, and distribution of mountain
mountain lizards, both inside and outside the tropics.

title_original: Reconstruindo a trajetória evolutiva da fotossíntese C4
title_english: Reconstructing the evolutionary trajectory of C4 photosynthesis
abstract_original: O metabolismo fotossintético C4 é uma adaptação a áreas quentes e secas resultado de múltiplas mudanças estruturais e bioquímicas na folha. Apesar de sua complexidade, a via C4 é um dos exemplos mais surpreendentes de evolução convergente em eucariotos, com mais de 60 origens independentes em angiospermas. Mostrarei como tenho investigado esse aparente paradoxo usando dados genômicos e ferramentas de macro e microevolução, em particular para inferir a ordem das mudanças genéticas associadas a via C4 , e se elas evoluem gradualmente ou em saltos, e elucidar os processos evolutivos em nível populacional envolvidos nas fases iniciais da transição para um metabolismo C4
abstract_english: C4 photosynthetic metabolism is an adaptation to hot, dry areas resulting from multiple structural and biochemical changes in the leaf. Despite its complexity, the C4 pathway is one of the most striking examples of convergent evolution in eukaryotes, with more than 60 independent origins in angiosperms. I will show how I have investigated this apparent paradox using genomic data and tools from macro- and microevolution, in particular to infer the order of genetic changes associated with the C4 pathway, and whether they evolve gradually or in jumps, and to elucidate the population-level evolutionary processes involved in the early stages of the transition to a C4 metabolism
